content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Neverending Nightmares is a refreshing psychological horror game. At first the artwork looks a bit rough and childlike, but in the end that's exactly what made the game so chilling. I also enjoyed the balance between gradual tension building and creative jump scares.Considering that there's nothing much you can do in this game other than walk around (and avoid a few monsters), the game is surprisingly entertaining. I got to the end credits pretty much at the point I felt that the game had started repeating itself. It takes a couple of hours to play through the game, but the story branches and there's some replay value.If you enjoy your creepypastas and don't mind the rustic charm of simple home baked games, you might want to grab this when it's on sale.

number of helpful: 13 of 25 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Full disclosure to start with: I was a Kickstarter backer for this game.Let me also get this out of the way: I'm not really a horror game fan.  I'm fascinated by the idea of horror games (as the fact that I have a number of horror games on my playlist will attest), but often lack the guts to actually install and play the silly things (as the fact that most of those same games have 0 playtime on them will attest).Given that, it was with a bit of apprehension that I loaded up the game this evening.  But I went all in for the experience.  The lights were out, the headphones were on, and I dived in.And I got to say that I enjoyed it.Neverending Nightmares tells the story of young Thomas, an asthmatic young man whom awakes from a nightmare in which his murders his younger sister, Gabriella.  As the name implies, that is not going to the last time that Thomas wakes up in this game.  Most of the game is spent wandering through a handful of environments, while the tension slowly builds around you.  I’m sure there will be people who decry this as “yet another walking simulator,” as Thomas cannot run for long before having to stop to catch his breath.  This exploration is punctuated by a handful of enemies, and a number of jump scares (I think all but one actually made me jump).  The enemies themselves act more as barriers than as active hunters (with a pretty notable exception), but nothing too aggravating to overcome.  The real draw here is the tense atmosphere.The tension is brought in large part by some amazing sound design.  The ambient soundtrack kept me on edge pretty much the entire time.  The enemy tells were also nerve-racking…and while not sound design, I wanted to give a shout out to some great use of controller vibration, using it to as another cue for the enemy’s footsteps.  Even the sound of poor Thomas gasping and wheezing to catch his breath after a full sprint was well done.  It made me feel bad for the poor kid, and I actually stopped sprinting as much because I didn’t want to hear it anymore!In the end, Neverending Nightmares is a short game.  I finished my first play through in an hour and a half.  There are a couple a sequences that I missed and intend to go back and play through, but all told I’ll be surprised if a full complete takes more than 2 hours (Update: it took me 2.5 hours to get all endings/branches).  In the past, that has been a major hang up for me.  In this case of Nightmares, however, I don’t mind at all.  I feel that I got my full-pledge value out of what I played.  It's a tight experience that delivers it's narritive and atmosphere, and then ends before it overstays it welcome. And I wouldn’t be surprised if Neverending Nightmares becomes a Halloween tradition for me.I also feel that the story behind the game is an important one.  The game is the director’s way of trying to express what it was like for him to suffer from depression and OCD.  But don’t worry, this isn’t a “game with a message” where you are beaten over the head with it.  It did cause me to consider what it must be like to suffer from mental illness when, after I played the game, I discovered that some of the more gory/horrific sequences in the game were inspired by intrusive thoughts the director had suffered from (I didn't even know about intrusive thoughts before then, if I am being painfully honest).  If you google 'Neverending Nightmares,' you will get linked to some articles where the director tells his story and his reasons behind the game in more detail than my lame attempt here.  It is well worth looking up.All told, I don't regret throwing my money behind Neverending Nightmares at all.  If you like horror games, pick it up.Update:I managed to reach all the endings.  According to Steam, this took me about 2.5 hours (on timer on Steam said 2, another said 3, so I'll spilt the difference).  I should note that, after I played through blind the first time, I used a guide to find the other two endings, so if you are keen on finding out those for yourself, it might take long.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Not great, but a pretty decent horror romp. The actual scares get very repetitive towards the end as you go through the same rooms and encounter the same enemies over and over and over again. Locations and enemies are unfortunately fairly stock: creepy old mansion, run down asylum, mutilated inmates, living dolls, etc... A few times the enemies actually managed to frighten me, but they were mostly predictable. This game is a fine example of why repetition can ruin horror. All that being said, the audio and visual design save this game from being completely mediocre. The sound in the game reminded me very much of Eternal Darkness, setting the mood of a rapidly shifting nightmare scape very effectively. And the hand drawn, line heavy art style is fantastic. Overall, I'd say it's worth your time, but try to pick it up during a sale.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												So far, I have only made it to one ending of the game. For the most part, the game doesn't rely on cheap jump scares for it's scare factor. The game itself makes you question what the heck is going on. As you journey through the game there are branching pathways that lead to different endings and different kinds of scares. The atmosphere and the sound design is what really got to me. I was constantly freaked out or even paniced, because of the events happening. This game isn't for everyone. It is a little slow, considering you're walking through it. There is a "sprint" but it's more like walking fast, and it doesn't take long for the character to run out of breath. The best way to enjoy the game is put on some headphones, turn up the volume, and see where your creepy journey takes you. I did get this a part of a bundle for pretty cheap. Honestly, I'd say $15 is a little bit too much for the game. Took me 2 hours for one ending. There is replay value if you want to find all endings. If you like horror games, I'd say give this one a shot. Thanks for reading! :)

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Um... yeah. It's not a good sign when I've only been playing the game half an hour and i'm already bored.The developer did a pretty good job building the atmosphere, but it feels like all it's used for is jump scares. The most I can say is at least it isn't one of those fricking flash games where you click on this thing five times, this thing once, once on the first thing, and then are rewarded with a really cheap jumpscare.Game play is excruciatingly repetitive. It is a clever gimmick that instead of "dying" you wake up, and it was utilized well during the first bit of gameplay, where you wander around an empty house waking up every time you see something particularly horrifying. I also love the black and white color scheme, with interactable objects having different colors to them. This was a godsend, and I didn't have to wander around smashing the interact button in front of everything that looks slightly unique.Trouble was, this is a walking simulator in the worst sense of the word. And I like walking simulators! But whereas in, say, Gone Home you are walking through a house that's loaded down with secrets and personality and notes and Bikini Kill and Le Tigre tapes, in this game you are just walking. Periodically jogging for a bit. Hiding in plain sight for a moment. Followed by more walking. There aren't notes. There are barely any other people. Even when the game did something I thought was really neat (introducing the girl with black hair from the trailer/game icon as your sister by showing a picture of you with her, then telling you her name by showing your character react to her tombstone, which reads "beloved sister") it goes and ruins it by having the character wake up and immediately have a conversation with his sister about how she is his sister.And I get where the game is coming from, I do. It's about mental illness. Mental illness is all about repetition, whether it's the good kind of repetition like stimming or the bad kind, like chronic unwanted thoughts. But when that's all there is to the game... life is just too short, you know?

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												I feel like this game might have done better as a short animation. The art style is really interesting to look at and lends itself well to the creepy atmosphere. The pen style drawing look makes the world around you far more unsettling. The music and sound is a great compliment as well and there were plenty of times I found myself on edge just from the noises around me, even when there was nothing actually happening. The entire set up should have lent itself to a fantastic horror game except it's missing the game part.There really was nothing to the gameplay here. Every so often you could look at a picture or the face of ever deteriorating dolls, but there wasn't much to interact with. Sometimes monsters would show up that you would have to avoid, but they were all pretty standard and as far as I could tell there was no real penalty for death if you screwed up.  All of them were simple to figure out and were very easy to deal with making them very non threatening. There were one or two times the game did something interesting with each individual creature, but it only ever happened once and then never again.Pretty much the meat of the game was walking slowly down hallways looking at artwork that you couldn't interact with. To make it worse a lot of the same visuals were used over and over and over again. The same creepy dolls the same creepy pictures the same unsettling blood splatters. What started out as unnerving quickly became dull and in some cases kind of funny because of how overused it was.Finally the story was a little... meh. It was nothing special to begin with then add on to that the main characters seeming disinterest in everything going on around him just made the world feel even more lifeless. With the exception of some of the "cutscenes" seperating the parts of the game you feel like you're controlling a paper doll. Dead body falling from the sky? Not a flinch. Seeing people hanging from the ceiling? Not even an eyetwitch. He just doesn't feel like a character let alone someone I should be concerned/interested in.This game obviously had a lot of heart and love put into it. It shows in the style, the atmosphere, in the sound design and how smooth the gameplay is when it does happen. It unfortunatly just doesn't have enough to hold it up as a game and definatly not enough to justify the price of it.I've only gotten one ending so far (the bad one I think) but I just don't think there was enough to keep me invested to try and get the other two. The first playthrough only took me 2 hours with me taking my time/looking hard at background scenery and out of that probably only about 20-30 min was spent on actual gameplay outside of walking forward.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Play as Thomas, the man who can only sprint for 6 seconds before completely running out of breath and panting like crazy on this linear adventure called "Neverending Corridors" as you traverse the same corridors over and over as you try to build stamina to overcome asthma, also featuring a fun game of tag with your sister who has perfectly functional lungs who mocks you for your disabilities, but Thomas never gives up and shows his sister that he can indeed catch up to her, it's very heartwarming.This could have been a 20~30 minute corridor marathon but it was meant to be an experience where you truly relate to the character and his chronic asthma, and because of his disabilities it actually takes two to three times longer to beat, I approve this game as an educative game to raise awareness about the struggles of asthma and how it completely changes life for the people who suffer it, asthma is a really scary thing indeed.

												Firstly I will state that I was a Kickstarter backer for this game, so you may think me biased if you wish.Neverending Nightmares is more of an 'experience' rather than a game (in fairness it does say that in the game description). As many other reviews have already mentioned, it is mostly walking around with very little gameplay, however (depending on your taste) I found this to be very enjoyable. I would also state it's more of a creepy game rather than a scary one. It depends heavily on atmosphere, but I found myself too detached from the main character, Thomas, to really find myself immersed. It had moments where I would find myself feeling rather tense, and it did have a few jump scares (effective and nicely done), but I never found myself feeling genuinely scared.The storyline is confusing and varied, but I found that very fitting. After all, how often do dreams make sense?The price is a little steep for what is essentially an interactive short, but I would recommend getting the game when it's on sale.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												I would recommend Neverending Nightmares at a discount if you are disappointed by short play-throughs. I, personally, don't care for game+ type of scenarios or running through alternate endings and such which might be something to consider also. With that said I beat the game in 92 minutes and I can say that my overall experience was pretty good.On the plus side, the sound is notably magnificent. I really like how the directional queues in the audio contributed to the overall awareness of your impending doom. It goes without saying that sound plays a major role in any scary game or game that wants to immerse you. Equally noteworthy is the art style. You may or may not like the hand-drawn aesthetic, but I like it, though it is worth noting the entire game is rendered this way. There are also a lot of explorable areas along the way to take in the detail if you're in the mood to appreciate the labor that has been put into the artwork.What I didn't like was the repetition. You will get winded after the first 30 minutes when, despite the inclusion of a few evil creatures, you realize the mechanics are a bit shallow. You look at things that have color, you push the shift key to run from creatures, and you try not to walk into the possessed inmates. That is the challenge in a nut shell, though it shouldn't take away from the real goal of delivering an enjoyable story which you can read all about in the game's description (it is pretty accurate).Neverending Nightmares is a trip, no doubt about it. The game would be a great way to kill an hour or two if not indulged upon in short bites. Check it out some time.Check out my profile for screenshots of scenes that disturbed me the most!

number of helpful: 19 of 38 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Stylistically, this game is great. The art style is amazing and the sound is well done. While not the most scary game, the atmosphere is pretty creepy. While it has a few jump scares, the game doesn't depend on them. This is a game you must play with headphones at night. That said, the whole package is really underwhelming. There's no combat in the game and the most you do is dodge the few predictable enemies in each section. If you manage to make a mistake, you restart in a room just before the one you died in. The enemy system is unchallenging and annoying, and rather than help the game, it makes it tedious.The game itself is incredibly short, and you can finish the first playthrough in less than one hour and a half. This isn't even rushing through the game, but exploring and examining the locations. Even getting through all the game routes, it'll be hard to go over three hours. I would be able to forgive this if it wasn't for the game biggest mistake: it's really repetitive. The first hour of the game is, as I said before, creepy and atmospheric. Then the game starts recycling assets and themes and the whole experience falls on its face. In the end you'll get one of three endings, and I'm sad to say, they're just disappointing (short, straightforward and not even clever). There's no reason for a game so short to be this repetitive and saying that it was intended to be that way is a terrible excuse. I mention that the game has a nice style to it, but there are games that do it much better, and for the current price ($15) it isn't really worth getting it.

content:

												It saddens me to say, this game is flat out boring.I was a backer of this game on Kickstarter, back in Sept. 2013, and the demo hooked me. I had several of my friends play the demo and they all backed as well.The only good thing about this game is the sound design, and maybe the art style at times.The story is whatever, the exploration is non-existent, there is no reason to do anything besides just keep holding down D or A to whatever destination you are going to. The monsters are boring and are just annoying obstacles you have to stop and wait to dodge. The extra rooms have absoultely nothing in them, no Lore journals, no scary spectacle, absolutely no reason to want to explore this game around. You constantly just want a change of the repetative sceneary, which happens very rarely. The art style is great, it was one of the reason I backed it, but when its the same assests reused over and over again, it gets stale very quickly.The most annoying part is how slow your character moves. Not only do they make you walk down the same hallways over and over, but you cant run more than five seconds or the character starts to slow down and pant very annoyingly. Its as if they want us to "take in" the game atmosphere by forcing us to slowly waddle through the game. After everything, I am very disappointed in this game. No, I dont regret backing this. It was a great idea and a great demo, but it failed to live up to what it could have been. I wanted so bad for this game to KILL in sales, because the main developers is an awesome guy.Unfortunately, this game does not deliver in any aspect, and I wish the best to the man who made this game. Good luck

												Unsettling, horrifying, ambiguous, and tragic. All the best qualities of a great horror game. I would highly recommend all 3 branching paths as the main enemy changes up and some paths are harder than others. The spine-chilling soundscape had me in a sweat more than the actual difficulty of the game, which is another sign of a great horror game. I've got thoughts about the story bubbling up in my head now, but that's up to you to discover by yourself and come to your own conclusions. The level design tends to twist on itself, repeating and restructuring, a bit like the Inception of nightmares where you're not sure if you're going the right way but you never get lost. It's a short but intense experience rather than drawn out filler where tension is lost, which I think works best for the genre.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Neverending Nightmares may be a short experience - taking around two hours to finish - but the paper and ink art style and oppressive atmosphere has combined into a very innovative and interesting game. More reminiscent of Limbo than any of the more conventional horror games I've played, the game creates a dark world with only one objective: keep walking.Though the third person perspective means that it can't do jump scares as well as most horror games, it nonetheless managed to create a feeling of dread throughout the game by focusing more in the psychological part of the horror genre. The slow building gameplay helps contribute to the dark and introverted feel of the game; though I found it wonderfully refreshing, not all gamers may enjoy what is essentially wandering around a dismal world for half an hour.Though it suffers from a few minor glitches with the lighting, it never really got in the way of gameplay and the branch-off levels add to the otherwise short game. It gets a little repetitive by the end, and the short environments show its indie background, but it's ultimately worth playing and is infinitely preferable to games like Dead Space which overly rely on jump scares.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												I've rarely seen a game start off so stellar, then nosedive. and then suddenly be over before it barely got underway. The first half is the most eerie gaming experience I've ever had—despite the abstract artstyle—to the point where I had to shut it off and calm myself down after just 5 minutes. The atmosphere is so well done that the game is worth recommending. Just. The game then changes locale and suddenly swaps out atmosphere for tedious, repetitive scenarios where all you do is elude zombie-type creatures, while you rely mostly on trial-and-error and the frustratingly slow pace of your character, who is exhausted after 5 seconds of sprinting. And then the game is suddenly over— after maybe 1 hour of play. The few interactive items in the game that seemed like maybe pieces to a puzzle, or a secret to unravel (mostly framed portraits) appear to be just things for you to pointlessly look at.To be honest I felt cheated paying what is the equivalent of $17 for this. Grab it during Summer Sale if it's there for like $5 just to experience the remarkably well done opening act, but this game feels like the developer(s) got lazy in a hurry.

content:

												I was a backer to the game. The idea seemed quite interesting at the time, but it didn't turn out well. There is/was no horror - some gore and attempts at jump scares. I'm being told I made choices at some point during the game, but I have no idea when, where or how.The entire game felt dull, very walking-simulator. I understand this game is supposed to be reflective or symbolic of mental illness, which I can relate to, but if there is some kind of message being communicated, it is completely lost on me. It is extremely short, but I have to say if it was significantly longer with no other changes, I probably would never finish it simply out of boredom.The pros of the game are the music and the art. The art is very unique and engaging. Some areas of the sounds get annoying at times (your character gets winded from running 10 feet and huffs as if they were a 50-year smoker) but it does communicate the atmosphere well.I wouldn't overall recommend it, but I also wouldn't write it off. If you are a overall fan of this style/genre, it's good to kill a couple hours at a cheap price.

number of helpful: 16 of 32 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Edit: I heard this game cost 100K to produce. For those of you that own the game, is this shocking?Ok I have a lot to say about this game. I like these creepy indie titles - this reminded me of Knock-Knock so I was all about it. Basically, you just roam around a series of rooms trying to find the right way (ultimately this game is quite linear path-wise). Can't find the right way? No problem, just manage to die and the game will start you very close to where you messed up (I was actually thankful for this mechanic many times because I certainly didn't want to repeat the random journey I just took). You roam around until you hopefully find a point where some bizarre little story moment takes place. This is seriously just a series of random nightmares, which leaves little for story room. Nothing *really* makes sense here (I mean we can theorize, but who knows). The art is top notch except a few little glitches (why does a light go on when you turn down a perpendicular hallway? Or why does the shading glitch out when you go through a door? -I look past most of this, but just for noting). Honestly, having the blood being actual color red with everything else black-and-white has also been done a million times before. It was cool the first couple times, but is now just cliche. The music and ambience is certainly creepy, and I am sure is awesome with headphones (I played with a group most of the time). My main problem lies in that there was nothing to figure out. No strategy or puzzle or game really. To be straight I am totally fine if it is just an experience, but this really wasn't that (I love Dear Esther, Gone Home, etc.). I played through to one ending, and only encountered two 'enemy' types that were both lame and frustrating. They were both stock 'walking  towers' that seem to have been added so it had a 'game' element. The running mechanic was also funny because that freakin' kid cannot even run half the length of the screen without weezing for his life lol.Ultimately, I wanted to feel connected to this game - it sure seems like a lot of love and care was put into building it. The whole time I just found myself wandering aimlessly around a house trying to find trigger points for the next cutscene. I think this title is worth $5 but not much more. I may play through to see one more ending, but I will certainly not get 10 or 15 hours (for $10 [on sale]) out of this.

number of helpful: 14 of 29 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												I was drawn to this game initially because of the very unique and interesting art style and the promise of dreamlike logic and storytelling. And, Ironically while I did indeed get both of those things I got nothing else. The gameplay is nearly non existent except for avoiding some very easy to avoid enemies (which is sad considering that the enemies are visually well designed and scary/disturbing) and walking from empty room to empty room which becomes exasperating as you learn that all of the rooms are basically copied and pasted over and over and over again. Puzzles are nearly non-existent and unless you have severe brain damage chances are you wont have to think very hard about any of them. Storyline is probably one of the weakest in any horror game I have played which was dissapointing considering I went through the trouble of getting all the endings because I thought that they may have all been connected only to find that they were not. The game starts with this whole little sister motif that could have been interesting only to derail into completely unrealated stuff about your wife depending on how you played the game and then no matter what ending your going for it just sort of ends suddenly with a ending that had zero build up.  It even comes complete with a "IT WUS ALL A DREAM!!!" ending which made me slightly angry at the laziness of it all. I dont get why this game is rated so highly, its not deep or well written, its not a good horror game, and its boring besides a couple choice moments.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Well.. Why do I not recommend this game?TL;DR: It is too expensive for the amound of time spent, mostly walking in one Direction with the occasional change of direction. And it isn't scary. At all.I have played it trough once, and I guess I will play the other endings too, sometime.First, the positive aspects:I like the gamestyle, it is something different.But what kept me playing was the question, whats going on.The Sound and Athmosphere were also really great. The game rarely scared me, but I was often on edge: "What happens next", "If I go there I bet something tries to jump trough the window", and so on. But only for the first 20minutes or so. Then the Cons shoiwed.Cons:The "monsters" - They really don't add a lot to the game, they seemed more like a puzzle to me than a scare, because they really arent scary. They are really, really dumb.The Level Design. Soooo much to walk around! If I had not been hooked by "whats going on here" I would have quit.Because at least 60% of the game consisted of walking "Right". 30% have been walking "Up", "Down" and "Left". the last 10% where interacting with things, mostly Paintings I still dont get the hang of, what they added to the game, I really have no clue,Not certain if positive or negative: I was almost never really scared. At the beginning there was a lot of anticipation and some really nice scares, building up atmosphere. But after that, it felt as if nothing was happening anymore. And I am one fellow who is easily scared. It took me ages to play trough Amnesia, not having finished a Machine for Pigs yet...But this.. well.. at least I did not had to take a break because I have been scared to death.Wait for the game until it is in a Humblebundle or similar.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Ok, so there you have the first analisis I wrote about the game the first time I finished it, and at the end my final impressions.First impressions:This has to be a joke. Ok, so the art is great, it's very atmospheric and it has some really creepy moments. But you simply can't sell at this price a game that you can complete in an hour. Yes, it has alternate endings, but it means that you are going to have to play the whole game again, a game that is already very repetitive, only to watch another ending but without any new playable experiences.The game has literally three different kind of hazards and like another three puzzles and that is it.And let me tell you, what is up with that part with the boy in the woods? it seem only there to annoy the player, the boy can't run for more than like five seconds and even running he is incredibly slow, and they make you run through an endless wood chasing your sister.And by the way, all that thing that the developers have been telling about the game being  based on the real experiences of someone who have experienced mental illness, so convenient that his condition involve a mental hospital, a creepy house, and all the oldest horror clichés.Shame on you Infinitap Games.Final impressions: Ok, so now I've completed the hundred per cent and played through all of what the game has to offer, you can check my profile to see that it's true, and that I have spent only three hours to accomplish this, considering that I have had to play to some segments more than once.Here is my conclusion, the game is extremely short and the sceneries and situations are used again and again. Many times, there is not even anything to do, only walk through hallways and hallways, entering rooms that have nothing inside and wait for the jump scares to appear. The game has a few really good moments, but really keep you waiting for more to come, something that gives sense to the whole experience that never comes. The game suffers from a lack of content, especially considering the price. I feel very disappointed, because this game had huge possibilities.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												I've unfortunately got to give this a thumbs down.I wanted to like this. I saw it on Kickstarter originally and thought to support it but gave it a pass. The art style is wonderful - kind of a Gorey / Gloom vibe to it. The music is good to adequate. The actual gameplay... well, for the most part, there isn't any. OK, sure, occasionally you'll have to run. Rarely. And you've got awful running ability, being tired out after 6 seconds to stop and rest. And part of my playtime was not realizing a certain enemy couldn't be run from... you're supposed to be quiet, so can't run. But that's it.OK, so what do you have? Unfortunately, you just walk. Slowly. And walk some more. And walk again. The few places you go are resused over and over, so even seeing what you see is not worth it. There's some scary stuff. Mostly it's a lot of gross out material, like showing different roadkill and saying, "Yup, that's road kill!" Or a doll with 25 different scary facial features each time. There is no game. If you boiled it down to what you can see the first time and interact with you got maybe a half hour of content. But playing takes hours that seems tedious to wait for the pay off... and there's nothing. No explanation, nothing over the top scary, nothing. And then credits roll.I got this on a huge sale, but I wouldn't pay that price even. This is a free Flash game at best. At the end you'll ask yourself why you spent the time. Don't pay for it on top of that. The art was great. The idea was great. If this was an animated 20 minute short you might watch it and even pay a few bucks. The developer obviously worked on it a lot. It's just not a game.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Edward Gorey.One of my favorite artists.  His dark, gothic style of cartooning has delighted the Victorian in people for years.  Now Neverending Nightmares takes his style and makes a game out of it, and just like Goreys style, in this game there are no good endings.  The controls are basic and functional and don't get in the way of the game... The art, which is THE reason to play this game doesn't quite ring true to Gorey but is very effective in getting the hopless sense of fear and desperation out of the game and into the player.  Only black and white is allowed in the pallette, with occasional visits from other colors... particulary red.  A simple mask of blakc lines over the front of the screen gives the omnipresent drearyness  a real sense of depression.  When a color does pop up the players eyes are immediatly drawn to it.The music fits very well, sound samples are played repeatedly with changes in frequency giving the body of the song rather than pitches or notes.  Whether is a twisted lullaby, or the screams of a lunatic in an asylum every part of this game screams at the player "Doom!  Death!  Hoplessness! Despair!" while using a the voice of a soft whisper.If you love dark things, Victorian novels, or are a fan of E. Gorey, you will be delightfully entertained ( and possibly pushed toward suicide ) by this game.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												I briefly watched a stream by SCXCR of RiverCityGamer (woo hoo, shamelessly self-promotion), and got immediately inspired to purchase the game, especially at the ever inticing 10% off sale.  I sat through the game with a pair of stereo headphones on and I have to say, the two things I immediately loved were the graphics style and the sound design.  I also enjoyed the fact that I'm playing a horror game where I actually feel fairly helpless, forcing me to figure out how each obstacle works and how I can avoid them, as well as be prepared to run the moment I 'hear' something coming.The only major thing that can hinder the experience is the fact that it felt too short.  There isn't a lot of variety and the game is pretty linear but does give you branching paths near the end which can change up the narrative.  Then again, I didn't expect much for a game that is suppose to represent Matt's personal demons, but other than that, I did genuinely enjoy this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Disclaimer: I know the developer, and am a fan of his work. That said, what's most compelling about the game to me is that it mirrors his own experiences with mental illness:I am channeling very specific imagery from intrusive thoughts that I've suffered from because of my OCD. Intrusive thoughts are these crazy thoughts that your mind comes up with for the sole purpose of upsetting you. In my case, I've struggled with thoughts of violent self-harm. I've actually re-created some of my visions in the game like pulling the vein out of my arm or tearing out an arm bone.What's powerful about games is that they give us the opportunity to experience things we normally can't. And in this case, it's not the result of a group of people sitting around a table thinking, "What'll scare the player? Hey, and who's ordering pizza?", but Matt Gilgenbach's interpreting some of what he's actually gone through.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												First things first, as you can tell from the screenshots this game is beautiful. It uses an Edward Gorey art style and for the most part it looks great in motion. Too bad that this game is an absolute chore to play. I really hope you like walking left or right, because that is what the gameplay of this game consists of. You will also walk SLOWLY. If you choose to use the run button you will propel yourself forward slightly faster for about 10 seconds before your severely asthmatic character runs out of breathe.So it's a "walking simulator". That’s fine, I loved Gone Home and I think games can push the envelope and focus on narrative instead of puzzles and combat. But games in the “walking” genre rely on detailed and interesting environments to make up for their lack of traditional gameplay content. Unfortunately the environments in Neverending Nightmare are made up of a few rooms recycled over and over again and are mostly devoid of anything meaningful to interact with.  This combined with the slow traversal speed makes this game tedious to play.Ultimately this game doesn’t benefit from being interactive and can’t recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game. I really did. And I tried my best to fully immerse myself in its dark atmosphere, playing with headphones, taking it slowly and all. It worked well for a few minutes, but then...the game ended. After less than two hours, it was over. And the ending was abrupt, weak and somewhat inconsistent. There are multiple endings, yes, but they are simply determined by which path you (blindly) choose in the last few sections, there are no big puzzles or significant choices to make during the course of the game. And seeing all of the three endings doesn't really make things better. They make everything confusing and nonsensical at first, they become clearer after putting a bit of thought into them, but still you are left with a sense of something missing.Neverending Nightmares is not an awful experience to endure, on the contrary it is filled with undeniable inspiration, but as it is it's a totally rushed and incomplete work. And that saddens me a lot, because it's a terrible waste to see a title with such a beautiful, deeply unsetting visual design and so much narrative potential fail to deliver something up to the expectations. It would have taken so little to make this game really beautiful and worth playing that I really cannot condone the way it's been presented. And it's just a terrible pity. I'm giving my thumb down with the highest reclutance this time, but I have to.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												Pros: The music is pretty good, and there were about two points during the entire experience where I thought the scares/images were effectiveCons: Sadly, aside from those two particular times I found all the rest of it to be dull, cliche set dressings on what were essentially empty rooms and hallways. Seriously, 90% of this game is walking down empty hallways that become more and more cluttered with either gore or eyeless dolls. There are other scary things out there, developer! Gore and dolls can be scary, but you kind of drowned the game in them to the point where they no longer have meaning. The plot consists of a few 5-10 second long spoken bits which includes the endings. I get that the developer wanted to leave things ambiguous and let the player draw their own conclusions, but the fact that there is no lore to collect and no narrative whatsoever means the player has literally no reason to move through the game. I wish the developers had put the same amount of effort into making a gripping narrative or lore notes to collect (they're a horror game staple for a reason) or any reason at all to drive players to continue pushing their character down those hallways as they did dressing up the endless, empty rooms with an insane level of detail (sadly most of which is same-y gore and dolls).This game would be hard to recommend as a free flash game. When I finished it and got all the endings I just felt like I had wasted an afternoon and a few bucks.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												This game starts out promising. With a fantastic art style and great ambient soundtrack it sucks you in, immerses you in its nightmare horror setting. But soon you realize there isn't much else there.The gameplay basically boils down to blindly walking through spooky rooms and corridors until you reach the end of the nightmare and you wake up in a new slightly different nightmare consisting of more rooms and corridors. Occasionally you meet one of several different types of enemies, each requiring a different strategy to get past, be it hiding in a closet, sneaking past or just running away. Once you figure out how they're easy to avoid. Most rooms are just empty though. The backgrounds look nice and detailed but only very rarely is there something you can actually interact with, and usually it just means a close up view of the object. Every now and then a loud noise will try to startle you, together with spooky or disturbing imagery. It tries to scare you, but personally I was never scared or even startled.Like this it continues for the 1-2 hours it takes to beat, and to be honest it's way too long for how little of interest actually happens. By the end my thumb was tired from having to constantly hold right on the left thumb-stick. That's what you'll be doing 90% of the time, just walking to the right.There is a vague story. A girl died and haunts your dreams. The game drip feeds you some bits and pices of the story throughout the game but mostly leaves you with no story developement until your reach the very end of the game where you might find out what really happened, or not, based on a couple of branching paths in the game. Fortunately there is a "nightmare select" menu so you can go back to these branches and choose a different path if you wish.Bottom line, it's a game with a nice art style, good sountrack and atmosphere. But it fails in the gameplay and story department. It might be worth getting at a discout but otherwise I wouldn't recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												Neverending Nightmares has a remarkable art style that can pull off both unsettling and innocent, but a great art style doesn't make a great game, and particularly not a great "horror" game. The game does have a foreboding atmosphere, I suppose, but at a certain point in the first half hour of play, you develop a rhythm to the game play. Your character has asthma, so can run in only EXTREMELY short bursts. This is not developed or particularly meaningful in a story context, so it honestly feels like a ploy by the developer to make you uncomfortable. You don't want to run ever because what if you need it when an enemy appears??It's an interesting premise, and it works well....for 10 minutes. After that point you know when the "horror" will appear. You are no longer engrossed in the atmosphere and the grotesque art. You are simply walking. And that walking lasts a LONG time. It feels as if the developer believed that uncertainty as to the incoming danger would last throughout the whole 2-3 hour experience. It does not, and as a result, the tediousness of walking and never running just bothered me, quite frankly. Was the art phenomenal? Yes! Was the game enjoyable? I suppose for a bit. Do I recommend it? Unfortunately not; it just doesn't do enough of interest to me to recommend.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												This game should be called Neverending Jump Scares and Walking. Seriously, all you do in this game is walk, very slowly I might add, and trigger jump scares. The devs added the capability to run but your character can't run more than 10 sec so I guess he's asthmatic.This game is clearly a personal message from the dev on something happening in his life but that's all it should be, a message, write in a journal and don't make games dude. This is hardly a game but more of a short story and it's not told very well either. I'm glad I got this in a Humble Bundle because I'd be furious if I spent $15 bucks on this. Actually, I'd be upset spending $5.Good:-Artwork is fantastic! I really loved the pen and ink feel. The black and white set a very good creepy tone and matched well with the story and setting.-Music and audio matched up well with everything and felt original for horror music.-I enjoyed the creature interactions and really liked killing my character off just to see what happens.Bad:-At times the artwork was so overwhelming with so many lines especially in the forest. There was nothing creepy about the forest walking scene because I was so frustrated at how long it took to get through WAY TOO MUCH WALKING and how busy the artwork was.-Boring story. I get the story, I understand it, it was just boring. The characters weren't interesting and the endings were dull.-TOO MUCH WALKING! Unless I can get something added to the story or some intersting scenes from walking away from the main objective then don't let me walk there. Out of all the cells you could peek into, only one did anything, and that was a very predictable jump scare. If exploration doesn't do anything then stop letting us explore. As a player I expect to find something when I go somewhere, but in this game you don't see anything unless you go towards the main objectives. It's like having a game where the very last room out of 100 has a boss fight but the game lets you enter all other rooms 1-99 but they are empty. What's the point?TL;DRI'd give the game a 4 out of 10. It's not something I'd reccomend to anybody unless they simply like original stories regardless of quality.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Full disclosure: I was Kickstarter backer. I'm going to remain as unbiased as possible during this review, but it's more likely that not that I'll have a LITTLE bit more buy-in than others and this might taint my opinion. I originally backed this project because I loved the art style as well as the commitment towards building something that didn't rely completely on jumpscares (I'm looking at you, Amnesia, Outlast, etc.). I'm seeing a lot of people saying that the ambience "doesn't build to anything". That it's too short and too linear. While I'll say that they're completely correct, it was the journey, not the destination. I thoroughly enjoyed the art style as it's used to great effect. As someone who grew up with "In a Dark, Dark Room", this nailed the look. The added frosting was the sound direction, which is nothing short of amazing. Pants turn to gasps. Gasps turn to wheezing. Wheezing gives way to helplessness. Music sets the tone of neverending dread. Some could argue that the cost doesn't justify the experience, but I disagree. I believe my Kickstarter funds went towards the exact game that was delivered. I don't regret backing this project one bit. I could complain about using the "psych ward" cliche as a means to deliver narrative, or that there was no real skill involved with beating the game, but that's not the purpose of the game. It's not here to make you reevaluate your life; it's here to be a nice, scary haunted house. A short ride that reminds you why you like scary things to begin with.It's good. Is it $15 good? I would say so, but I'm a lone voice. If you're looking for the next Amnesia, or you're looking for something you can play over and over again for long durations, move along. If you're looking for a nice experience of dread and can part with your $15, you could certainly do much worse.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Stylized, creepy and short and MUST be played with both headphones and a game pad with vibration.  Missing either of the latter two will cause you to lose a good 50% of the atmosphere.  Great for Edward Gorey fans.The game's strengths lie in atmosphere, sound setup and visual style, all of which are very strong.  It also does some rather clever things with checkpoints in a way that is not clear until you've gotten more familiar with the game.  It's weaknesses lie in the limited experiences offered.  The game could have been more, and one enemy in particular adds an obnoxious game mechanic which is initially clever and then very tedious.  It also fails to provide any really satisfying endings.  Finally, it's got very little replayability as once you've gotten all the endings there's little reason to return except after a long abscence after you've forgotten the pitfalls.Your enjoyment of Neverinding Nightmares will largely depend on what you look for in a horror game.  Thankfully Slendy -- who showed up in the demo -- is removed from the final version.If you're the kind of person who enjoys being creeped out, this does a pretty good job.  This isn't a game played for depth, but it does an excellent job with providing a unique experience your first time through.  If the art style doesn't do much for you, chances are the rest of the game won't.  If you enjoy Creepypasta however, this might be up your alley.Warning for those squeamish about blood and gore: some paths are pretty nasty from an imagery standpoint.Is it worth the price tag?  Depends on how much you value atmosphere.  I don't regret purchasing it, but others might not be as satisfied.  It's definitely something to get if you enjoy Edward Gorey stuff.  I would advise AGAINST looking at a Let's Play of it until after you've experienced most of what it has to offer as it will basically spoil the entire experience.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Neverending Nightmares isn't so much a game, as it is an odd bit of art.  The stylized graphics and Victorian setting charmed me from the get-go.  For the past two years at PAX, this game has managed to catch my eye, even through the massive sensory overload brought on by the myriad of other games screaming for attention.  Suffice to say, it has been on my radar for a while.Did it live up to my expectations?  Mostly.  The real strength of the game is its ambiance.  It absolutely must be played alone in a dark room, headphones cranked, with controller vibrations enabled.  The creepy music and sound effects blend smoothly with the visuals, first creating a sense of unease, which gradually ramps up to dread with a dash of "oh holy ♥♥♥♥ing hell that's disgusting."  The jump scares are definitely a big part of it, but far-between enough that they don't lose their effectiveness.  But back to my original point--it's really not much of a game.  I'm not sure what I was expecting.  Having played the demo, I suppose I thought it was going to be a puzzler.  Explore hallway, find candle.  Explore dark hallway, find axe.  Open blocked path, continue.  And on, and on.  I was kind of hoping for a horror-themed Myst.  Instead, you will spend the vast majority of your playtime creeping slowly through a (more or less) linear path, building tension for the next gruesome cutscene.   Objects that you can interact with are sparse, which is disappointing in such richly detailed environments.  It made it all the more confusing when there were special "interactable" gold-framed portraits scattered throughout the game.  It took me a while to realize that these weren't some sort of puzzle element, but rather rewards for people who contributed a certain amount to the kickstarter.In short, this is interactive artwork, depicting a spiraling descent into madness inspired by the developer's own struggle with mental illness.  As a game, it's not exactly what I had thought it would be, but it was an enjoyable way to spend a few hours.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												My first exposure to this game was a Let's Play by Lotus Prince.  At first glance, this game could easily be dismissed as not scary.  It certaintly doesn't look like a lot of the modern horror games.Do not let quick impressions fool you, this game is a wonderfully creepy, scary and just disturbing game.This is definetly a game to play with headphones if you can, the sound design is amazing.  Not only is there a mix of unsettling music, there is also plenty of background sounds that really start to get to you the longer you play.This is also a game to play in big chunks, the more breaks you take, the more the atmosphere is broken.  If possible, try and play through to a finished path in one sitting.I've currently gotten all three endings and I won't share any of the details here.One of the strengths of this game is there is very little to interact with.  Too often horror games have you working on finding puzzle clues or weapons or health items.  This game you are limited what you can interact with.  The lack of busy work really helps draw you into the surroundings, and you'll find things in areas you thought weren't scary yet, slowly starting to disturb you greatly.It also makes what you CAN interact with, and see more clearly, have that much more impact.Yes, there are a few moments of jump scares, but this game is a lot more about the nature of being trapped in this nightmare, where you keep thinking you're waking up and escaping, and you're not.Yes, I was one of the late backers after this game was fully funded and started to play when the Beta was available.  That doesn't make my review or praise for this game any less.  Hell it was seeing the Let's Play that made me want to help be a backer and be a part of this game.This game has many moments where the sudden disturbing imagery made me turn away, though nothing in the realm of going too far.  Honestly some moments in this game reminded me of nightmares I've had myself, which only added to how emersed I was.Also, do not seek a strategy guide, you'll figure out all the branches eventually.  Let youself find them alone, it's a much better story that way.It took me a few times through some areas to figure out how to get the different branch, which helped the game feel very worth the price.If you like to be scared by more than gore and things jumping out at you, this is game is definetly worth a try.

												I enjoyed playing this game for the first time.  I intentionally avoided playing the betas, but I did play the kickstarter demo.I found this game very interesting as it it clearly focused on the creep and scare factor.  There were only a few spots that took some some more serious "gamer attention" to get past.  I actually enjoyed how when I made it past a part, it was not going to have to be repeated if I failed the next.There are some very thoughtful aspects to the game.  It was rather calculated in making the player feel safe at certain stages of play only to turn it upside later for a scare.  I feel there was a lot of effort on this aspect as there are plenty of "walk through parts" which were part of building suspense.The art style is what drew me to the game initially, as it is not a naturally scary style in the first place.  Hence it is a real challenge to make it scary.   However, I will say that the musical score is absolutely spot on and adds a tremendous amount to the game.My main con for the game is that it could be longer.I would recommend this game.  In fact I have, but unfortunately it was too scary for all of them.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Let me get the general ruling out of the way first: this is a great game from a new and promising voice in the indie horror game scene. It tries new things and often does things by its own rules, and it does this effectively, while also following in the footsteps of tried and true horror classics. It's not for everyone, but fans of personal, artistic, exploratory games as well as fans of atmospheric horror games (as opposed to action/survival-based horror) should buy, enjoy, and support it.That said, the game is not without its flaws, and a number of them have to do with pacing.Hallways sometimes seem to go on a touch too long without much happening. It's a strange feeling, getting *bored* by a horror game. Luckily, several times I thought maybe I was started to get bored, something terrifically terrifying would happen and put my♥♥♥♥♥right back on the edge of my seat where it belonged. Perhaps these moments would not have been as effective without the moments of calm, but I feel that the game would have been *more*, not less, effective if a few of the rooms or hallways would have been cut.That's not to say that all of the "pointless" rooms should be cut. It's kind of wonderful to be walking down what seems like a cookie-cutter hallway, enter a side-room, and find some new, unexpected, grotesque scene that, while serving no clear ludic function, ramps up the chills significantly and sinisterly.By the end of the game, though, the player will likely become a little desensitized to blood and guts intended to convey scenes of horror. At the beginning, the bright sight of red blood against the beautifully pencilled black and white is a shock and reminds us that not all is well in this mansion. By the end of the game, there seems to be more red than white at times, and it becomes just another part of the macabre scenery.Don't get me wrong, though; throughout the game, the gore is often used to wonderful effect, throwing guts in our face when we least expect it. While I'm not usually a fan of cheap jump-scares, this game does have a few, and they don't at all feel cheap. In fact, I think each and every one was greatly executed.The art, overall, is quite nice. The way the seemingly-hand-drawn shadows scribbled their way over the light is a very cool effect and works well in the nightmarish context. The set-pieces and enemies in particular have frightening designs, especially as the game descends deeper into madness. One enemy, though, just wasn't particularly scary or fun to deal with. Luckily it doesn't show up very often, but a few of its behaviors seemed to be a bit out of place with the rest of the games. While another, later enemy hit the sense of adolescent terror just right, this one was more obnoxious and almost silly. Other than the one, though, the enemies overall were extremely effective from both a gameplay and horror perspective.The sound design and music are quite lovely, if you can call it that... aside from a few background ambience that sounds like someone doing an impression of a tortured Droopy Dog. I appreciated the way the music would evolve over the course of the different nightmares and a "new" nightmare's beginning would be indicated by a shift in the music as much as the narrative.The endings (the two of three that I've played, at least), while narratively intriguing in their own rights, seem to happen just a tad too quickly and feel like they lack the weight I think they deserve. With this kind of short game I don't feel necessarily like *closure* is what's needed, but the credits seemed to start rolling quite quickly and suddenly, as if someone came into a movie theatre after the last words had been spoken and hurried the audience out so they could make room for the next group or something. That said, I like that the endings don't necessarily agree with each other. They all come from the same background, but come to different conclusions of varying depth that indicate what's **really** going on here, and I think that was a smart and cool decision.Overall, there's a lot to praise in this game. It's at its best when it embraces nightmarish weirdness to try to throw the player off track, changing placement of rooms and playing with expectations. The lead developer, Matt Gilgenbach, has referenced *Metal Gear Solid* and *Silent Hill* as influences, and in this way they both shine through, but without becoming overbearing. If there's an ultimate takeaway, it should be that this game is a unique experience that I highly recommend. Also, supporting this game means supporting future titles from the developer, and personally I'm *very* excited to see what Gilgenbach and Infinitap does next.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Make no mistake; this is a psychologycal horror game in the truest sense - It's a game that through it's main gameplay loop (an endless awakening into another nightmare) explores the developer's daily struggles of OCD as well as intrusive thoughts. It's all presented in an Edward Gorey-like artstyle, that also brings to mind the works of Edgar Allan Poe. Even more intriguing than it's artstyle is the absolutely fantastic sound design which consantly keeps the player tense for the horrors to come. Is this the scariest horror game I've ever played? Well, no. But like the best games in the psychological horror genre it focuses on being thoroughly unsettling throughout - a feeling that intensifies upon reflecting on the real life mental struggles that inspired it. Common complaints target the game's short length and the lack of player interaction - but to me these miss the point. The game should be judged by the emotional journey it takes the player through, not by some commercial formula of "X hours of gameplay for Y amount of money". To me this is a great game, and the few complaints I do have - i.e. some of the character animations, lip-syncing - are likely to be addressed through updates, and don't detract from the raw human emotion and pain conveyed through the experience. Two thumbs up.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Ugh, I do wish there were other options besides "Yes" and "No".  Cuz this game would get a "probably not" from me.This game is decent, but it's just not good enough for me to recommend it to people.  I'm not going to bother going over what the game is about since you can see it from the trailers and description in Steam.So the pros:* Very interesting art style.  I actually thought it was very neat.* Some pretty effective freak-out moments (this will also be in the cons; it'll be explained)* Interesting progression.* Pretty interesting base story, though the reveal was a bit anti climactic.Cons* Repetitive.  I get it's supposed to be, but it started to get to me a little bit because of the next point* Thomas is the most out of shape, slowest person ever.   He has two modes.  Walk (where he walks slowly) and "Run" (where he looks like he's running but he's walking at slightly faster than our normal walking speed).  Not only that, but if you "run" even just one step, Thomas starts breathing heavily.  Look at your bedroom right now.  Imagine running from one side to the other.  Thomas will take 5x longer than you and he'll be out of breath.  This is what makes it repetitive.  Because you have to go through very similar rooms over and over you want to get thru them fast if there's nothing interesting in them.  But he walks so slowly and gets out of breath so quickly it gets annoying.* Not only that, but apparently running even just one step is like the loudest thing ever.  Like I'm running in a long hallway because it's a long hallway and all of the sudden I hear a noise and the blind crazy dudes come running out of no where and pounces on me to kill me.  Great.  The way this SHOULD be done is if you run and the crazy dude is on screen at all they should make a noise and run in your direction.  If you stop, they should stop and look around unless you're with in a certain distance from them.  But no, they can not be anywhere on screen and if you run a single step, they'll come a'runnin'.* There was one part of the game where it was actually impossible.  I died about 15x because they blocked off the entire hallway except one small area.  They had a blind crazy man patrol the area.  He started where it was blocked off and ended where it was blocked off.  After about 15 deaths, the guy finally spawned in the place where I think he was supposed to (he wasn't patrolling the bottleneck anymore).* The big babies were fairly absurd.  In Amnesia and Outlast if you try to hide while the guy is right next to you, they obviously know where you are and will grab you.  In this game, you can jump into a cabinet while the guy is right next to you and they'll get confused.  Really?* Many of the scares are of the "jump scare" persuasion.  That means sudden image accompanied by a loud noise.  Yes, it makes you jump, but IMO it's a very cheap way of getting a scare.

												If you're thinking about buying this game, stop it right now and find something else. I'm going to go into full spoiler detail here so if you for some reason still want this 'game' then stop reading and understand it's your own fault for making such a poor choice with you money.Now spoiler alert, the game is walking to te end of a hallway several times in which if you see a door above you don't wory that's either an empty room or just a checkpoint room. Now you might ask what do you need checkpoints for? The insta kill enemies (which there are only three kinds of) which are all just a slight variation on the oh so amazing gameplay stratgey of walking around them slowly. I say walking because the dev team decieded to not just remove the run feature but cripple it to the point that I would suggest just never using it. There's no punishment for not running either, it's just how long you want to waste walking through halls with nothing to see. Also any 'scares' the team added were something you were thinking about an hour before they did it. Oh look some windows I hope nothing appears while I'm walki-Oh hello jumpscare good to see you again FOR EVERY SINGLE WINDOW I WALK PAST. The story is nill, you get the impression your sister died when you were young and you're stricken with grief because you promised to keep her safe and that makes you crazy or whatever so you're locked up in a looney bin. I can't stress this enough that there is no game here, the first minute of gameplay is repeated without change until you finish the game. I've played games free flash games with more anything really. Also I'm sorry but the visual style isn't nearly as cool as they thought it was, it turns any scene into a laughable mess.TL;DR This isn't a game, and you shouldn't waste your money on it.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
First playthrough time: 2 hoursAll endings play time: 3.5 hours totalMajor Pros:Great sound and musicMultiple endings and story paths allow for replayability and story map easily lets you hop to the part you want to playGood use of some traditional horror themes and restricted vision levelsMinor Pros:Interesting art and color useagePleasant eerie elements background elements give the place a haunted feel, but could've been used more"Jump scares" not overusedMajor Cons:90% of the time you don't need to go in any of the rooms other than the one at the end of the hallwaySome early monsters feel repetitive while others make it feel like an action game (later monsters were much better)A fair amount of the game is walking through uninteractive sceneryMinor Cons:The color-bordered pleasant pictures on the walls detract from the creepy atmosphereStory is a little unclear and might leave player feeling like they still have questionsI found the game very interesting and really liked the art. The different levels and parts of the story, especially with the different endings, were very enjoyable. My favorite level is probably when the dolls start coming to life because I felt it gave the player the right amount of anticipation when traveling between rooms. I think the game struggled a little with "empty rooms" where the player is just trying to get to the next hallway. While "empty space" is necessary so the player doesn't always expect something to happen in every room, I think there was perhaps a little too much here and it can draw the player out of the horror feel if nothing's happening. Never the less I enjoyed the game and played through all 4 story paths for the 3 different endings.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												This is an interesting game that provides some chilling moments during play.  The story of Thomas Smith, while simple, pretty much makes you think a little, maybe even make your own conspiracy theories.  Both the atmosphere and the sounds give you a chill, and I'm impressed that the game manages to spook you without the use of the over-used jump scare.  There are a few problems, though.  You can finish one of the story modes in no time, I say about 45 minutes to a hour tops, so you might complete the whole game, if not collect all four achievements, with 4-5 hours.  Also, whatever enemies there are in the game aren't the scariest things ever.  You can easily get past them with the most obvious way possible.  Only thing that could make getting past the enemies more obvious was to put in neon signs, and the ones that chase you will give you at least a little bit of a problem.  That being said though, the reason why people play horror games is to get scared, and in that regard, I think it does a good job.  If you're looking for cheap jump scares, like most indie horror games do unfortunately, then this is not the game for you.  Otherwise, this is a game worth experiencing, though the length might effect how much it's worth.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												This game is extremely atmospheric. While the graphical style is very interesting, what moved me most was the extremely creepy (and intensifying) music as well as the excellent sound assets. However, there is something you definitely need to know: The game is short. Even with branching paths the game only takes a few hours to finish. And it must be said that there is relatively little replayability once all the branches have been unlocked and all the levels played. In light of that, the price point might be an issue for you, so you might want to wait for a sale if you don't mind the wait. However, it's less of an issue if you think of it like a movie in the cinema. A couple hours worth of entertainment for a few bucks, but I can certainly understand if you want to wait for the DVD release to keep the metaphor going. If you pick it up, though, make sure to get the full cinematic experience: Darkened room and headphones. Use a gamepad with rumble if you have it for smoother controls and more feedback. Overall a very enjoyable if short ride.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												For horror fans who want something besides typical jumpscares. I'm sure those familiar with atmospheric horror games, like Silent Hill will find shared ground with Neverending Nightmares.Neverending Nightmares is about the mind of Thomas and his love for his sister, Gabrielle. In nightmares, or as I'd call this more a night-terror, people who are close to us tend to take the brute of the darkness. This "Edward Gorey" styled game is all about immersing yourself inside this bleak nightmare and the sound makes a huge part of that, so headphones is recommended (and turn off the lights and play it by yourself for more intense effects). As the nightmare continues, you make choices that can alter where the horror takes you. For better or worse, the choice is yours to make. And don't worry, if you thought that nothing was after you in this game, you are sorely mistaken. I won't divulge exactly WHAT is coming for you, but use your imagination. But I do warn the faint of heart, there are cringing moments and disturbing scenes, not quite on par with Saw, but gets close with its self mutliations and morbid topics like suicide.If you're not paranoid, jumpy, tense, nervous when playing this game, you're probably playing it wrong or it's not your cup of tea.Now that those remarks are done. My thoughts. I must say wait for a sale on this game, in my opinion, for as little content as there is in this, it's not worth the $15 price tag. Cut off $5 and I think that would be reasonable. The game offers very little as far as replayability, so if you like your Amnesia custom stories, might want to look elsewhere. I've spent almost 90-120 minutes on this game and I've completed everything. Granted, I've been a little spoiled and I was playing it wrong for much of that time. Which is why I say to savor this and play it like you WANT to be scared. Creeping along dark hallways with nothing but a candle to keep you away from the shadows and unerving sounds makes a very tense and slow moving pace. Afraid that if you run, you might run into something you won't be able to escape or hear coming over your own breathing and footsteps. This game sets a great atmosphere for those willing to take the steps and immerse themselves into it. If you feel like you're lost, just keep walking. The labyrinth of the mind is very easy to get turned around in, so just keep pressing on and you'll head in the right direction in this game.Closing remarks, the game is great for those willing to dive into the atmosphere. For those requiring more action and jumpscares, look elsewhere. Bring the price to $10 and I'd definitely recommend buying it. Perhaps if they added in some other endings, this game could have some more replayability.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												The subconscious can be a truly dark and frightening place and Neverending Nightmares propels this notion to the forefront. You play as Thomas, seemingly forever stuck in a perpetual nightmare/sleep state. He dreams in black and white, he dreams of death and murder. Creepy broken dolls lay strewn within the walls of his home. He dreams of monochrome tombstones and blood stained asylum walls. But...is he really dreaming? The game forces us to accept dread, fear and vulnerability. Thomas cannot wield weapons, he can't fight. All he (or you) can do is survive. The gameplay mechanics are very straighforward. Directions, sprint and an interact button. That is all. But do not take this simplicity for inadequacy. The game is very unsettling. The scares are very well crafted and will make you think before making your next move. There are equal parts subtle and obvious scares. Neverending Nightmares is an exercise in psychological horror, throwing you in between worlds and catching you off guard in the process. Cheap jumscares are a thing of the past and Neverending Nightmare gets my vote for progressive horror gaming.If you're looking for a different kind of horror, the kind of horror that is deep rooted within your subconscious, then this is the game for you. My only regret? Not playing this in online mode, so now I have no achievements. But that's ok because in my opinion Neverending Nightmare has a high replay value and three different endings to keep you entertained (and afraid).If you'd like to see my take on this brilliant game, go here :

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												A solid, creepy horror game. The art style is distinctly inspired by Edward Gorey, and works well for the Victorian era home and asylums the player character must chart a sometimes uncertain, often dreamlike, though mostly linear path through. Some minor branching is present, though I have not explored the alternates. The sound design is excellent, with competent voice acting, the ambient sound, effects, and music do wonders for instilling a creepy vibe throughout the experience. Gameplay is fairly shallow, with the player rarely having to do more than continue walking in a single direction, continuing on in spite of the sometimes suffocating atmosphere of dread.Enjoyed the game, but your mileage may vary.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												I was one of the Kickstarter backers for this game, having fallen in love with the initial concept and the teaser trailer. A psychological horror game inspired by the experiences of a man suffering from his own very personal, genuine psychological horror? Count me in. As both a lover of horror and as someone who is fascinated by what makes other people tick, this game seemed a sure-fire hit (to me).Does is succeed? Sort of. I'm giving this a thumbs-up because I feel emotionally attached to it as both a backer and a horror enthusiast, but I can't say I wasn't a bit let down. There is very little gameplay to speak of - minor stealth sections are fine, but they grow repetitive quickly. I don't want to write this off as a walking simulator, because 1) I hate that term, and 2) I love walking simulators (Dear Esther, to me, is a stunning work of art). However, there just isn't all that much to this game. Keep walking right. Look at another portrait. Go into another empty room. Wake up in a different bed. Walk right again. Meh.The best part is the atmosphere. The soundscape is truly stunning. Play this game with headphones, please. I've haven't heard audio this precise and well-designed since the original Thief games. And the visual style is simply gorgeous.I love thte idea of multiple endings, but slogging through the same corridors three times again to find them all was too much.Buy it, play once for the phenomenal atmosphere and a few good scares, but don't expect too much from it.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												I havent gotten to the last ending yet (tried two times and got fed up, lol) but I've basically played most of it.This game, has EXCELLENT atmosphere. Its subtly creeepy, so little so that you can actually play this alone in the house, but at the same time, so much so that you'd wish someone was hugging you while you played.  While there are jumpscares scattered, its not very much and most of the times, the thing to suffice spooking you would be the atmosphere. Which may get old after a while.The storyline on the other hand.From the start, you don't learn much about what the eff is going on. All you know is that your Thomas, and your supposed to just walk walk walk. and find out things. It does sort of draw you in, but I should say that the two endings I've experienced so far were quite a let down. They were effective, short, and they made sense, but, it still was a letdown.Gameplay itself is repetitive, you're just walking and there are a set number of "enemies" which you mostly avoid in two ways. Setting of scenes mostly follow the nightmare you happen to be playing. It's sort of otherwordly, but not otherwordly enough such that you'd be staring at the art with awe. (Im guessing Silent Hill would be where the art makes you stare like woah wtf) But the cutscenes really make yu go woah wtf (because seriously... wtf is going on) and some of the scenes (related to the jumpscares) do make you go WTF as well.Would I reccomend you to buy it? When it's on sale. But for a 'cash strapped' 18 year old, do I regret my purchase? nope.
