content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												This is an interesting game that provides some chilling moments during play.  The story of Thomas Smith, while simple, pretty much makes you think a little, maybe even make your own conspiracy theories.  Both the atmosphere and the sounds give you a chill, and I'm impressed that the game manages to spook you without the use of the over-used jump scare.  There are a few problems, though.  You can finish one of the story modes in no time, I say about 45 minutes to a hour tops, so you might complete the whole game, if not collect all four achievements, with 4-5 hours.  Also, whatever enemies there are in the game aren't the scariest things ever.  You can easily get past them with the most obvious way possible.  Only thing that could make getting past the enemies more obvious was to put in neon signs, and the ones that chase you will give you at least a little bit of a problem.  That being said though, the reason why people play horror games is to get scared, and in that regard, I think it does a good job.  If you're looking for cheap jump scares, like most indie horror games do unfortunately, then this is not the game for you.  Otherwise, this is a game worth experiencing, though the length might effect how much it's worth.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Disclaimer: I was a Kickstarter backer and followed the game's development closely. Perhaps I expected too much. I know from the post-release emails begging for good reviews that this isn't what developer Matt Gilgenbach (who clearly tried really hard and cares deeply about the game, to his credit) wants to see, but I feel it's my duty to provide an honest review to combat the frankly ridiculous amount of hype.As others have said, this barely qualifies as a game for starters. I'm not against "experiences" and "digital novels" (I enjoyed Dear Esther, even), but this just doesn't feel like anything. I even disagree with the positive comments about there being decent tension and creepiness - it's a disappointing mess of cliches: creepy dolls? Check. Random dead stuff? Check. Horror movie-style insane asylum? Check. And seriously, for a game allegedly about mental illness, was that last one really in the best taste?The story is practically non-existent. Just when I thought it might be getting started, it ended. I honestly had to check to make sure it wasn't some weird bug. It really feels like the devs ran out of time.The thing that piqued my interest in this game though, the sole reason I backed it, was that it's supposed to be about mental illness. As someone with a long history of mental illness myself, I was excited to see a more believable, more intelligent treatment of the subject. Boy was I disappointed. In all honesty, I see nothing relating to mental illness in this game besides the lazy cliches you find in pretty much every horror title (see above).As far as I'm concerned, the art direction is about the only thing this game gets right. As others have said, the black and white, hand-drawn style is fantastic. But there's no way it's worth anything close to the asking price.Sorry, Matt. I really, really wanted to like Neverending Nightmares, but it just doesn't deliver. I don't regret backing it, but I can't recommend it either.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8
												I'm very disappointed that I have come to the decision to not recommend this game. I tried to justify a recommendation so many times through my playthrough, but in the end, I simply cannot.I would like to start with the positive qualities of this game. The sound design is amazing and the graphics and animations are very unique and interesting. It succeeds in creating an intense and terrifying atmosphere despite its story book artstyle.I was absolutely in love with this game for the first thirty minutes, however, the experience got bogged down by bad design choices and over indulgence.  There are two enemies of a horror games, boredom and frustration, and unfortunately, this is exactly the two flavors that remain in my mouth after my playthrough.  The game makes a hard turn from disturbing imagery to challenging puzzles, which was a bad choice.  In each stage, there is a unique type of monster that blocks your way, unfortunately, it is only one kind of monster.  This game would have benefitted greatly from adding one or two more types of hazards and each environment. However, it is the puzzle design that I found so frustrating.  A good puzzle game will teach you the tools necessary for you to solve the puzzle and then throw a curveball. In a good puzzle game, the player should be constantly flipping between the feelings of the puzzle being easy and the puzzle being impossible. But this is not what happens in Neverending Nightmares. Instead, it turns into a pixel hunt, where you are trying to find the little trick to each puzzle by peering through the  murky sketches. An example of this:  one puzzle requires you to step on a piece of glass in order to draw out the monster, but up until that point, the game has taught you that stepping on glass always results in being killed.  I had to resort to watching YouTube Walkthroughs, and the Youtubers frustration cemented in my mind that this design was flawed.  In a horror game like this, you should only be dying when the game decides it's important for the story. But, there is a mixture of scripted deaths which push forward the narrative and cheap deaths from failing to avoid an enemy that led to confusion and, eventually, took the atmosphere and horror out of the game.Furthermore, the game is relatively short. My first and only playthrough ended up being roughly 1 hour and 40 minutes but there was probably 45 minutes of content. A little bit more restraint in the level design and the number of rooms and encounters would have greatly helped tighten it up.  I found myself throwing my arms up and asking the game what it wanted me to do.  There are multiple paths and endings, but I will not be going back to explore them.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												I played through Neverending Nightmares for the first time last night. My Steam record says I played it for 1.7 hours (I didn't take a break). So, indeed, the game is rather on the short side. Still, it managed to capture me and I was focused on the nightmares 100% all the time. The gameplay is simplistic: Walk around with WASD/Analog stick, interact with Space/A button, sprint with Shift/B button. There is no actual puzzle solving, the focus is set on exploration and finding your way around. As the character is weak, he is unable to fight and has to flee/hide from enemies. Also, he can sprint only for a short time, eventually stopping to get some air - fleeing has to be well planned. This gameplay "limitation" reminded me a lot of the original Silent Hill games, where protagonists got worse at combat and having to breathe after running around for a long time.The presentation is rather unique. I believe most of the nightmares are supposed to take place in a castle of the 19. century, and the hand-drawn sketchy art style helps you time travelling into this nightmare world of the past. Lots of details help you navigate through the castle, but also disorientate you on purpose, by shifting corridors and rooms and replacing wall paintings, wardrobes and such. While the game starts almost fully black & white with a minor amount of colored objects (those you can interact with), the amount of disturbing elements (blood, body parts) increases in time. The pacing in this buildup has been done really well, in my opinion. There are jump scare moments, but they are anything but cheap, they rather support the already uneasy atmosphere. The character and enemy design is convincing enough, though I wish there were more of both kinds.As stated already, I recognize a lot of inspiration taken from the Silent Hill series - such as the character entering holes and staircases going deep down multiple times, but there are more examples. Neverending Nightmares is a great way of telling nightmare stories. While it doesn't involve much action and interaction, the scariness comes from your imagination, as you start to recognize how this believable world slowly turns into a true nightmare!I would recommend the game to people who don't put their focus on action/combat, but rather atmosphere and exploration. If uncertain about this, maybe wait for the game to go on sale!

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Some games are thrill rides.  Some games are merry-go-rounds.  This game is a dark ride.  It doesn't try to be anything else; it completely surrounds you with its atmosphere and takes you to another world, and like the best dark rides, that other world will haunt you long after you get off.I would put this game firmly in the "art game" category, and so immediately some people are going to be turned off.  It's not a terribly long or challenging game.  It will only take a few hours to play through it, and it won't take much longer to get all the endings.  There are enemies and it is possible to die, but the enemy encounters are very simplistically set up and the penalty for dying is a relatively tiny slap on the wrist.  There aren't any puzzles, and the game holds its cards very close to its chest in regards to story.However, this game isn't about that.  It was designed entirely around the experience of playing it, and it is an experience that you're not going to forget any time soon.  The hand-drawn graphics are striking, the music and sound design are excellent, and some of the unsettling, disturbing, and violent (and oh, man, this game is violent) imagery will probably haunt me for the rest of my life.  It's paced very well to maintain a constant, rising tension, and the short length ensures it doesn't overstay its welcome.  The controls and interface are incredibly simple.  You move with the cursor keys or WASD, there's an interact button and a run button.  And that's it.  There's no inventory, no puzzles to solve, no health or resources to manage; you just walk around and look, progressing further and further along the linear path ahead of you.  What is truly remarkable is despite how simplistic it is, and how little challenge the game offers, the accessibility still doesn't come at the cost of atmosphere, which is amazing and suffocating at times.  The major theme throughout the whole game is mental illness, which, despite the scariness and the gore, doesn't feel exploitative at all.  It's approached in an very understated and tasteful way, and I think anyone who has ever had some kind of mental illness will immediately be able to connect with the player character, Thomas.If I had to make any real criticisms about the game, I would say that the endings come a bit abruptly and I would have liked to see more variety in the enemies.Overall, I wholeheartedly recommend you buy this game, especially if you're looking for a good horror game for Halloween.  It's a stunning, unique, and simply horrifying little game that, despite its brief length, you'll be thinking about long after you step away from your computer.  And besides, we need more quality horror titles like this; so play it and support the tiny indie studio that made it!

												Some games are thrill rides.  Some games are merry-go-rounds.  This game is a dark ride.  It doesn't try to be anything else; it completely surrounds you with its atmosphere and takes you to another world, and like the best dark rides, that other world will haunt you long after you get off.I would put this game firmly in the "art game" category, and so immediately some people are going to be turned off.  It's not a terribly long or challenging game.  It will only take a few hours to play through it, and it won't take much longer to get all the endings.  There are enemies and it is possible to die, but the enemy encounters are very simplistically set up and the penalty for dying is a relatively tiny slap on the wrist.  There aren't any puzzles, and the game holds its cards very close to its chest in regards to story.However, this game isn't about that.  It was designed entirely around the experience of playing it, and it is an experience that you're not going to forget any time soon.  The hand-drawn graphics are striking, the music and sound design are excellent, and some of the unsettling, disturbing, and violent (and oh, man, this game is violent) imagery will probably haunt me for the rest of my life.  It's paced very well to maintain a constant, rising tension, and the short length ensures it doesn't overstay its welcome.  The controls and interface are incredibly simple.  You move with the cursor keys or WASD, there's an interact button and a run button.  And that's it.  There's no inventory, no puzzles to solve, no health or resources to manage; you just walk around and look, progressing further and further along the linear path ahead of you.  What is truly remarkable is despite how simplistic it is, and how little challenge the game offers, the accessibility still doesn't come at the cost of atmosphere, which is amazing and suffocating at times.  The major theme throughout the whole game is mental illness, which, despite the scariness and the gore, doesn't feel exploitative at all.  It's approached in an very understated and tasteful way, and I think anyone who has ever had some kind of mental illness will immediately be able to connect with the player character, Thomas.If I had to make any real criticisms about the game, I would say that the endings come a bit abruptly and I would have liked to see more variety in the enemies.Overall, I wholeheartedly recommend you buy this game, especially if you're looking for a good horror game for Halloween.  It's a stunning, unique, and simply horrifying little game that, despite its brief length, you'll be thinking about long after you step away from your computer.  And besides, we need more quality horror titles like this; so play it and support the tiny indie studio that made it!

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2016
												I'm sorry, but this is one of the most boring and uninspired horror games I've ever played. In the hour and a half it took to get through the game I kept hoping for Anything mildly interesting to happen, but in the end I just felt like I had wasted my time.You play through a series of nightmares that all consist of walking through corridor upon corridor in such groundbreaking and refreshing settings as ~an old, abandoned house~, ~a psychiatric hospital~, and ~a graveyard~. I expected there to be some absurdity, maybe some surreal looking areas - these are nightmares after all - but there was hardly any to be found.Occassionally you will come across monsters that you have to get past to get to the next boring corridor. Some you need to hide from, some are blind but will attack if they hear you, etc. Pretty standard horror game mechanics, nothing new here either.Now, I could live with the boring gameplay and paint-by-the-numbers horror elements if only the game had an interesting story to tell, but even the story is about as trite and clichéd as they come. In the description it says the game was inspired by the creator's struggles with depression and OCD, but I didn't see anything that gave me any insight into what it was like to deal with that.I say this as someone who's struggling with mental illness myself, and am a little dissapointed that you'd use that as a selling point for something that only ever comes across as yet another horror story about some guy fighting monsters in a surreal alternate world because of a traumatic family incident. It never feels personal at all, it just falls flat.Also, apparently the game has multiple endnings, but it gives you no reason to want to replay it, so I don't know what the point of that even is. If you want to play a game where it feels like you're fighting mentall illness, play Knock Knock. If you want to play a game with a similar quirky children's book style, play Fran Bow. Both are much better horror games.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Neverending Nightmars seems to derive horror from ever-presant dread rather than shock. There are some jump scares but they are few and far between. Areas are large and exploration requires a fair amount of endurance. This combinded with an increasingly oppressive atmosphere really create a kind of horror that you don't often see in games. I rarely felt frightened, more disquieted. It's a slow burn that builds up over time as you feel more and more out of control, a feeling aided by the modest control set.I will say, for people who dislike a "less is more" design philosphy, Neverending Nightmares can leave something to be desired. In spite of how quickly the game can be completed, there are segmets that seem to stretch endlessly. Combined with the reuse of art assets this can break the tension and create dull moments. A player expecing more direct engagement or variety could be disappointed.That said, I feel like these are intentional design choice. The game is crafted to express the thoughts and experiences of the lead developer's struggles with mental illness, specifically depression and OCD. Much of the explorative gameplay feels as though it pushes you to look at everything and leave no path unobserved. For my part, this evenually left me somewhat inured to the shock value of the esclating horrors while me general unease persisted. It was a very interesting experience and left me with plenty to mull over after the game's conclution. Regardless of any shortcomings, I feel that the style and vision expressed in Neverending Nightmares makes for a completely worthwhile experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												having just had a few moments to start the game my review will be brief. first some disclosure. i did back the game on kickstarter after trying the demo. however i didnt back enough to get alpha/beta acess so im not as spoiled on the game as some others may be. i will say this game isnt for anyone if youre looking for a challenge or even scary monsters or lots of jumpscares. this isnt the game for that. the game is atmospheric  with the audio and visuals presented to you in a way to try to unnerve you. the back grouds becoming worse in their conditions as you progress. some i have seen have complained about the characters movement speed and i know this will sound like a flimsy excuse. but if you stop to think about it. the character is in a nightmare and in nightmares you barely ever move as you would for real. i also dont know about many of you but if im in a strange envrionment where i feel threatend im not going to run like the wind and draw attention if i knock something over. the asthma aspect is something i find intersting and i like theres a limit.  i also find some of the images ive seen on my own playthrough so far and  LPS ive watched make me reach for that body part in sympathy. now whats not to like about this game? as ive said its not for everyone. like in a nightmare ive seen some places loop for a bit and start to mesh together but i dont think it detracts from the game unless by the time you reach the end of the first part of the asylum youre already bored or frustrated.  which i can see some people being.second the lack of jumpscares challenges or alot  of monsters. these may be common complaints from players coming into the game looking for something to scare them  most of them having played games like outlast or five nights at freddies or amnesia. honestly those games dont appeal to me where this one did. i like the fact that theres no challenge and instead of being frustrated or being jumpscared or chased for the hundredth time i can get myself immersed in the world the creator made. all in all i would reccomend giving the game a shot or watching an lp of it i can understand some saying the $15 price tag is a bit much and if youre hesitant wait until a sale. i believe this creator has some potential and would love to see him make one more before passing judgement on his abilities. i see this game as more of a window into the suffering of someone whose had dark thoughts and nightmares and how probably during those times he never felt it would get better.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												A lot of people think that Kool-Aid Jammers are just for kids, but I disagree. They're my particular favorite when it comes to pouched drinks, on top of others like Capri Sun. While they may not be as healthy as the others (but then, none of them are particularly healthy, really), I've found that Kool-Aid Jammers have a stronger flavor than the other brands, and don't have that watered down feeling that some of the others have. My personal favorite flavor is Cherry, and it's usually the only flavor I buy - there used to be a Cherry Limeade flavor that was better, but they seem to have stopped selling those. Kool-Aid Jammers might not be the best drink you could get, but they're good, fast drinks for when you want something with a stronger taste than water but want something more hydrating than a soda, with the convenience of a pouch meaning you don't have to take a lot of time away from your game to grab one.The reason I'm talking about Kool-Aid Jammers instead of Neverending Nightmares is two-fold; not only did my Kool-Aid Jammer outlast the game, but I also found it more interesting. Nevending Nightmares is a game that puts up a nice face in terms of atmosphere and art and sound design, but quickly falls apart when you actually play it. The game is, as the title implies, about a character experiencing neverending nightmares. You wake up in your bed, walk through one of three environments, and at the end something kills you and you wake up in the next nightmare. This goes on for about one hour (for a game called Neverending Nightmares, it sure does end pretty quickly), and then the game ends. Every now and then it'll bring in mechanics familiar to horror game fans, like a monster that you have to hide in a closet to avoid or an enemy that you can't sprint by, but these are few and far between and the enemies are so basic that it doesn't even feel like an effort to avoid them, let alone anything that might make you feel nervous around them. The only reason I even know what they do when they catch you is because each of them do it at least once in the scripted next-level death. The art style is unique, and the audio is well-designed to boost the atmosphere (though the special "headphones" sound option it encourages you to use seemed more like it was meant for bad headphones than ones more suited for gaming, and on my Gamescom 780 it just pushed all the sound to the front speakers of the headphones instead of giving a good surround experience), but so much of your time spent in the game is spent just walking past almost identical rooms over and over until you finally stumble upon the thing that kills you, and it's just not very entertaining. I'm not saying I want some PewDiePie youtube fodder game full of jump scares, but it's just hard to stay invested in a game with this little substance. There are apparently three additional levels that I missed leading to two different endings (though I have no idea what I did to "choose" the path I ended up on, since there isn't really anything in terms of dialogue or obvious story), but after seeing how long and tedious the final nightmare in my branch was I really just didn't care enough to see the others. I really wanted to like this game, but in the end I just found it extremely repetitive, and while some games make good use of down time to build up the atmosphere for a payoff, this game just feels like nothing but down time, leading to an unsatisfying conclusion that just leaves you wondering what the point was. Neverending Nightmares currently costs $15. A 10-count box of Cherry Kool-Aid Jammers costs $1.88. You can do the math yourself.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												Took a bit over an hour to get a first ending, about the same to see the others after that, with level/nightmare select and a guide.I'm torn about this one.I love the subject matter, I love that it is a very personnal project. Lots of cool ideas. Love the graphics. The audio is awesome. But I ended up liking the whole a lot less than I hoped I would.As a game it fails for me. Except jump scares (ok, there's a couple of nice ones) it wasn't scary to me. Creepy? Sure. The audio is the element working best at being oppressive and unnerving. Having no clear goal is a problem, that leaves exploration. But the levels are so empty that it wasn't fulfilling. There are no puzzles per say, you just progress in a rather straight line and double back when you find a dead (no pun intended) end. There are very few interactive elements, and a lot of those a rather bland, like many family portraits that are never of any use or reference to anything as far as I can tell. There are a couple of ennemies to dodge or run from, and if you die to them you'll restart in a nearby bed and do it again, or maybe it'll be one of the few story related ones and it'll make the 'story' 'progress' which inside of a level is basically redoing close to the same thing, but with slightly more messed up decoration and little less light.I do get the link to depression. Helplessness, repetition, little control over things.. As a statement I can appreciate it. As a game, it is just that: repetition. Maybe having my own battles with depression makes all of this a bit more mundane to me, I don't know.It is also just too slow for me.. Between wondering what could be the next jump scare and the slooooooooooow walking pace of the character, I found my mind drifting away, bored. Single elements, graphically, are really well done, but with so much repetition in tone, it becomes too samey to be scary to me.So. Is it good? Not really. Is it bad? Not really, either !! It is a cool thing expressing Matt's experiences, but I don't think it is a great game as is. I do wish for such things to exist, and I did pledge towards Matt's second title's KS (and would again if a 2nd attempt is made). If you're reading this still, you're probably curious and open enough to want to give it a shot, and to such people I would absolutely recommend a try. If you found this almost at random and are looking for a game-game, this is a harder sell to say the least, unless you're really easily unsettled and scared by disturbing imagery.

												This game so desparately wants to be P.T. It sets you up in an endless loop slowlly navigating the same hallways over and over again, with variations each time. Unlike P.T. you will feel no sense of physical danger or terror. I think worst decision the game made was to have an actual script. To top it off they chose this ridiculous and obnoxious visual design that will actually hurt your eyes.TL;DR: P.T. wanna-be that fails to delivery even fundamental aspects of horror.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												I've been playing the OUYA version of the game mostly, but will be putting more time in on my PC as well.   The added sharpness of the visuals and having headphones available on my PC makes it an even more enjoyable experience, but both are quite impressive.After about an hour of playing, I have to say that I am very impressed so far.  The game creates a wonderful level of tension and gradually builds up the story and atmosphere.  The noises and visuals blend well together to create a unique and wonderfully tense experience, which can lead you to get started are even panicy at times, as you race to avoid especially troubling encounters.This is definitely one of those rare games that makes you realize that it is very possible to transcend from a "gaming experience" into a true form of art.  I highly recommend it, especially to fans of horror in any of its forms.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												This game had a lot of things about it which I thought were very good but I can't bring myself to recommend it as over all it was rather boring. The art style is nice with the dark, detailed, hand drawn style but the over use of bright red blood negated the impact for me as it made it seem overly childish. The music and sound effects are excellent especially they way the sound effect subtly herald the approach of an enemy. The music together with the visuals create a great atmosphere that reminded me of the good silent hill games in places. The story is disappointing it starts of with mysterious hints as to what is going on but never really develops. I suppose they had to keep it vague to get it to fit in with each of the different endings but it just felt like it was going nowhere then suddenly an ending happened. The main problem is that this game mostly involves slowly walking through very similar corridors until something happens causing you to wake up and repeat the process. howlongtobeat.com suggested this game would take 1.5 – 2 hours to complete so I started this game with the intention of playing the whole game in one session but after an hour or so I was too bored to carry on. On another occasion after dying and waking up I took a wrong turn and inadvertently started heading off in the wrong direction, because the levels are so repetitive I did not realise this until I had got all the way back to the very beginning of the section. I guess the repeated similar environments were supposed to give the impression of being trapped and heighten the sense of horror but in the end it was just boring.

Posted: October 3, 2014
												This game is short, but it has greater impact than many other horror and scare games that last much longer.  Neverending Nightmares grabs you right from the beginning: there is no tutorial that overstays its welcome; a control guide; or even an hour-long opening sequence before you dive in.  Instead, the game begins immediately, and without any GUI to distance you from the action, you being your neverending nightmare...The graphics and atmosphere are very unique, and the hand-drawn nature of the game really helps establish a surreal setting that only increases in horror and intrigue as you progress.  The audio is integral to the experience, and pulls you in even further to this cacophony of mind-bending, psychological distortion of an adventure.Having said that, the length is bad not because it's too short, but that it feels like there's so much more story and setting to explore.  The game doesn't overstay its welcome, but it doesn't really stay for dinner either.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												Tedious, frusterating, poorly balanced and overall, not fun.In terms of good points I'll say the creator has a excellent art style and made sufficently horrifying. Unfortunently thats where the good points end.You know how most games have distingushing features in their levels and streamline the design so that the player knows where they are in the level design and don't constantly wander back and forth wondering if they're going the right way towards the next object that will progress the plot? Well, this game doesnt, and because of the constant reused assets I kept wondering whether I was going the right way or whether I had inadvertantly backtracked and needed to reverse my course.In itself that would only be a moderate annoyance, but theres also the issue that the levels have way to much *nothing* in them. Out of the time I spent in the first area, I estimate only about 10% had an event in it, either a scare or a monster or something to do, the rest just being padding going from one room to another.And when stuff does happen, its not well balanced. In the second area, I wound up having to get from one scene to another without being caught by zombies, but there was no way to tell where the zombies were in the screen other than trial and error, there was no way to lose the zombies if they did spot me due to how slow my character ran, and even if I did know where they were sneaking around them was nearly impossible due to how small the areas were, so I would constantly get caught, die, get sent back to the last checkpoint, repeat ad nausium.Honestly, this is one of the worst indie games I have bought and played. I cannot recommend it to anyone except horror junkies who've played everything else.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Neverending Nightmares isn't your typical horror game. It doesn't rely on jumpscares or even the fear of a jumpscare; instead it build's a creepy and disturbing atmosphere through sound design and the effective shaded 2D art-style, which makes blood really stand out. The game follows Thomas, a man seemly stuck in a world of his own making and your task is to somehow escape. The game plays off imagery of depression and suicide to build a world where we, as the player, are not only afraid but also sympathise with Thomas' plight. The story thread about Gabby is contradictory and often leaves you wondering who this women/girl actually is, with different areas of the game offering different explaination.My one complaint is that a lot of the same enemies and enviroments are used far too often and the game is FAR too short (i completed the beta in about an hour). But I would still recommend for horror fans!

These guys understand that the cornerstones of horror are isolationism, helplessness, and heavy atmosphere. It does all of them quite well. There are times, however, where certain monsters are used a bit too much and they can slow down and even break the experience. Once you get past those little parts though, there's PLENTY of good stuff. These parts with too many monsters number maybe.... one or two? I don't know what else is in store for me but in about 2 hours of gameplay, I've come away with a very satisfactory horror experience.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												This game is really good but unfortunately, $13.50 SGD of price makes me wonder if it is justified. I finished the game as well as to find all the endings, all in 3 hours (It was meant to be 2 on mine but it was actually 3 hours because I started from the middle of the game itself sometimes). Would I recommend it? With some hesistation, yes. Wait for a discount would be better.Nevertheless, the game brings out a different horror genre itself. Other games scares you with well planned jump scares. This game however, makes you uncomfortable to the core and adds mental stress to you at times, which should be a psychological horror genre game. The atmosphere can be pretty scary and freaky too.The art style of this game is inspired/ originated from Edward Gorey, which gives a distinct style as if everything is drawn out with ink. The intensity of black horizontal lines are the marks of bright and dark areas. The game has only black and white unless there are objects that you can interact with or there is blood (red).The level design is great and because of the art and colour style, the players do understand what can be interacted without the help of a tutorial though the enemies do take time to figure about on how to avoid them.The sounds are really aiding with the atmosphere as well. It's distorted, the music is weird and is out of place and makes you more uncomfortable. If you play the game, be sure to wear a headphone. They have made it so that the experience is more immerse with headphones.This game is an unforgettable experience and I would give it 3.8/5

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												This is a game that I have been waiting quite a while for, and had extremely high expectations for while following the developer up to release. I feel that it hit every goal that I hoped for and expected it to.It's not a game that focuses on cheesy jump-scares and 10-15 mins of constant fear. It's a game that offers a glimpse into the underside of our humanity and makes you feel like you're being torn from the inside out. The themes are powerful, and leave you thinking through the game and long after it's over. The art style is unique and well done. The soundtrack is ominous and goes quite well with the atmosphere that the user is placed in.A couple things that I did not like a about it though, that the hallways were a bit repetitive at times, and that the replay value is a bit lacking.It's not the type of game that gives you a shallow terror that ultimately leaves you feeling unsatisfied. It brings you to the edge of your seat, but also gives you time to process information and build up a feeling of dread and angst. A quality that quite a few games are lacking now.In my opinion, this game is well worth $15.00.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												While the aesthetic and sound design is fantastic, Neverending Nightmares is flawed. The use of colour is excellent and I have a weakness for eerie whispers. Later in the game the sparse and occasional blood spatters begin to become the usual décor which loses the promise it once had of violence and horrors.As for the pacing, we play as a sickly child who can run for about 5 seconds before he must take a break to wheeze desperately and collect himself. When he isn't breathlessly fumbling along, he staggers at a snails pace. The enemies and threats this game provides feel no more forboding than a slightly deformed picture of a kitten. Interacting with them does not cause fear, but rather it brings the already slow pace to a crawl.I found myself wanting it to be over but it kept dragging on. The jump scares were predictable and over all it was an unsurprising and tedious experience. I respect the personal nature of this game, and I think it's absolutely awesome for the devolper to use the medium for expression, but as a game, I don't recommend it. Or maybe I'm just jaded and hard to please.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												This is an interesting game in that it's not as much about the story, or even the abject horror, as it is about conveying certain emotions.  Matt Gilgenbach, the creator of Neverending Nightmares, suffers from depression and OCD, and this game exists to help convey what that is like.  The player will experience anxiety, dread, and general discomfort.  Of course that is because there are jump scares and monsters that are trying to kill him, but the point is the feelings that are transmitted.  The visuals are inspired by Edward Gorey, and of course incredibly disturbing, and the sound will keep the player on edge at all times, especially with headphones.Neverending Nightmares does have a story, but it's disjointed and intentionally vague.  There are three endings, but none of them are canon.  You can try to put the pieces together to create a cohesive whole, but it's like having 450 pieces of a 500-piece jigsaw puzzle. Connections can be made, but you won't necessarily get the whole picture, and that's the point.  Clinical depression is not a rational thing.  There is not always a reason for people to feel depressed, except that their brains tell them so.  Be aware of this when you are trying to interpret the story.The game is also heavy on symbolism, from the enemies to dream tropes that are lying around, like blood, teeth, and even the player's own slow running speed.  While the entire game, if you go for all of the endings and branching paths, will probably end up taking less than 2.5 hours, I would still argue that it is worth the purchase for the unique experience it provides, as well as for its part in helping spread awareness of OCD and clinical depression.  This game is great, and I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Neverending Nightmares is a horror adventure game thats 2D and all hand drawn but will you want to play it ? In Neverending Nightmares you play as Thomas who is unable to wake up from nightmares. Everything leads into a new nightmare.So how is this game ? Its quite good honestly. The game was made by a person who suffered from mental illness. So ill try to explain how the game is played. You walk around in a 2D enviroment and you walk from door to door till you go deeper into the nightmare and once the nightmare wraps up you have the ability to go back and replay them and try to get a diffrent ending and theres three of them. The game also throws a few enemies to the mix and all of them act diffrent. The game is quite suspensfull and sometimes frighting to say the least. But the game has a few issues as well. A confusing layout which is hard to tell where youve been and where you are. The game is incredibly short only under an hour if you only plan to get one ending. Neverending Nightmares is also quite pretty to look at and it really has outstanding sound effects too, i highly suggest you play in the dark with headphones. Overall Nevenending nightmares is an excellent horror game for fans of the genre and i suggest everyone to pick this game up just to see how awfull it is to have a nightmare let alone never to wake up from one. I give Neverending Nightmares a 7.5/10

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												A horror adventure with focus on atmosphere and emotions. No puzzles, not really challenging. But when you put on your headphones and if you let yourself drag into the darkness, sadness, hatefullness and bloodyness of this game you will enjoy a short but intense experience.And be aware: This game contains some really drastic graphical violence. (not joking!)Matt Gilgenbach, the maker of this game, wrote on his blog about his goals with this game: "As you may know, Neverending Nightmares has many goals besides to just scare the pants off of people. Expressing the feelings of mental illness is important to me because:    I’d like to promote a greater understanding of mental illness, which will hopefully remove some of the stigma associated with it.    I’d like to reach out to those who are currently suffering and show them they are not alone because I think there are a lot of commonalities between my experience and everyone who has mental illness."- http://www.infinitapgames.com/2014/09/04/a-heartwarming-story-about-neverending-nightmares/- http://www.infinitapgames.com/

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												This is not just some old horror with cheap scares and cliche antagonists. This is an artist's expression, the developer's impression of their own first-hand experiences with OCD and depression. It will have you on edge, heart in your throat and begging for an end. But you can't stop.The art style is very bleak, with few colours (usually on interative objects) and reminiscent of a childerens' picture book, which reflects well with the game's story and message. The gameplay is very basic, almost being an interactive story, but with the occasional challenge when you come accross one of the game's few 'enemies'.That is all I shall reveal, if you are looking for a horror experience that looks futher than cheap cliches, this game is for you. Give it a go!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												I must admit it took me some time on deciding if I would reccomend this game or not but the crucial question to ask yourself is how much are you willing to pay for something a little different.THE GOODYou should know that this game is certainly not  a "must play" but I do give credit where credit is due. The penciled in artstyle with highlights of color is certainly interesting and is something I really enjoyed seeing compared to so many dull, grey, 3D horror games. The images in the backgrounds are also very well done with plenty of both overtly horrific images as well as many subtly disturbing images. There are also a few jump scares sprinkled throughout for good measure but they are spaced far enough apart that they dont become tedious. I should also mention the sound design is really quite supurb. When using headphones you can hear plenty of slight noises such as whispers or footsteps that increase the dramatic tension. Last of all the price is fairly reasonable. I was able to buy this game during a winter sale for $6.75 USD which is less than I've paid for much worse games.THE BADThe biggest complaint you will find from myself and others is the lack of player agency (walking simulator is in the tags for a good reason). The actual gameplay largely consists of only walking forward and avoiding enemies and even when avoiding enemies it's a simplistic affair as you will likely only die a couple of times before recognizing a pattern in the enemy behavior. Another major issue is that the game manages to be both short (about 2 hours for 100 percent completion) and yet tedious. You'll see many recycled hallways that you'll have to run through with the shortest invisible stamina bar in the world. While this repetitive nature does help the game feel more like an actual nightmare that you cannot escape from it does lose its charm fairly quickly.CONCLUSIONIf you have a few extra dollars in your steam wallet and want to try a different but short horror game give Neverending Nightmares a try! For anyone that is looking to get the best for their money this one may be worth a pass.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												Not much to say, you wander through locations and sometimes try to find paths around wandering things that are out to kill you or run from them. You get the first ending after only about an hour or two depending on how slow you take it and your skill level. There's four total endings, most of which are just what doorways you go through.I recommend it. There's nothing in terms of mechanics other than walking and running, and there are three real jump scares by my count other than when you get killed. Its actually the fact that they really accomplished the feel of being in a nightmare that makes me like it. Playing it, I actually remembered nightmares that I've had throughout my life and probably haven't remembered since waking up on the day after I had them. Scared me more than a video game has since the first time I played Fatal Frame 2, and I don't know how long its been since I've seen a horror movie as scary. Don't pay more than $8 for it, wait until there's a sale. There's not enough here for above that price. The game actually tells you to play it with headphones, and trust me when I say it isn't for cheap jump scares but instead for more immersion. Play with the lights off and alone too, with a vibrating controller if you have it.

												I started off enjoying this game, but the incredibly repetitive monsters that were once scary quickly become just straight annoying. The plot began as if there was a puzzle that you could piece together, but after a while I realized that none of the puzzle pieces were made to fit each other. In short, Started out fun, quickly became an eyesore and repetitive, ending was tried too hard to be open ended and up for discussion.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												At first it seems like it takes after Lone Survivor,  but Neverending Nightmares has more in common with Dear Esther.  There's very little gaming to do.  All you do is march down long hallways, listen to the moody music, look at the creepy imagery, and eventually you get to the end.  Some may even compare it to Amnesia: The Dark Descent, but that game had plenty of things for the player to do.  It wasn't just a forced march down dark hallways; you had goals, and the monsters were actively chasing you!Having little to do gamewise isn't necessarily a bad thing.  To The Moon was very much like this, but what set that game apart from this one is the story.  To The Moon, Lone Survivor, and Amnesia all have a complete story to uncover at the end.  Neverending Nightmares does not.  It leaves you with a bunch of confusing pieces of a story with no resolution--yet another game that thinks being vague is the same as being profound.  (I'm looking at you, Braid!)All you do is march down long hallways, open doors, march down more long hallways, and at the end of the march is a jump-scare.  These jump-scares are effective, but after the fourth time, it becomes routine.  Oh yes, and dolls are creepy.  We get it.  Dolls *are* creepy.Neverending Nightmares feels like it was built around its soundtrack.  The levels are ridiculously long just to make you absorb the music.  The ambient horror music makes this game, and it does a very good job creating atmosphere.  The art style is especially memorable.  I've never seen a game look like this, and it adds a lot to the creep factor.Steam won't let me give this a neutral rating, but it deserves one.  I didn't hate this game, as it did a very good job creating atmosphere and jump-scaring me more than once, but I found the delivery more tedious than scary, and the 3 payoffs at the end do not provide a satisfying resolution to all that marching.

Posted: July 9, 2015
												Oh the ambiance. The suspense that this game creates is unreal. While the actual jump scares it provides are trivial things that happen, it's enough to get you heart to skip a beat, or maybe even three or four at times! But that's not what this game is truly about. This isn't a jump scare game at the heart of it, it's a game that creates this world of just insane creepiness that keeps you looking around the room every few minutes (especially with headphones!!!) and keeps you on the edge of your seat, and tricks you often with fake jump scares that aren't even really scares at all, it's just your mind being so freaked out it scared itself. That's what this game does, it creates such an ambiance that it doesn't even need to scare you, it just has to let you scare yourself. Great game, love it.

												First things first: Why does Thomas run SO SLOW? He runs short of breath with a 5 second sprint. I know there isn't much chasing in this game, but how slow the protagonist really frustrated me, especially in my second play through. I have asthma irl and even I don't wheeze like that after a few seconds of casual jogging. I am on the fence about recommending this game. For the original price of $15, I'd say wait for a sale. It's a well done game as far as atmosphere and music. I really like how they adapt the sounds for headphone wears.I like the style of the art, even if the blood effects look way too red and cheap - like they were pasted on after the fact. The story... well- I played through two endings so far. I like it, and I like how you can try to piece things together yourself. However the game feels much too repetitive.  I would of liked a lot more interactions with items in rooms. Most rooms were empty and dead ends, with simply nothing to do in them.The style is great, like I said. It's unique and we all need more Devs that explore different styles. For me though, the game doesn't draw me in. I wanted more from this game, but it just feels unfinished over all.I would still recommend it to other fans of the horror genre, especially those starved for something different than the usual FPS/crafting survival/zombie etc etc game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												At first it seems like it takes after Lone Survivor,  but Neverending Nightmares has more in common with Dear Esther.  There's very little gaming to do.  All you do is march down long hallways, listen to the moody music, look at the creepy imagery, and eventually you get to the end.  Some may even compare it to Amnesia: The Dark Descent, but that game had plenty of things for the player to do.  It wasn't just a forced march down dark hallways; you had goals, and the monsters were actively chasing you!Having little to do gamewise isn't necessarily a bad thing.  To The Moon was very much like this, but what set that game apart from this one is the story.  To The Moon, Lone Survivor, and Amnesia all have a complete story to uncover at the end.  Neverending Nightmares does not.  It leaves you with a bunch of confusing pieces of a story with no resolution--yet another game that thinks being vague is the same as being profound.  (I'm looking at you, Braid!)All you do is march down long hallways, open doors, march down more long hallways, and at the end of the march is a jump-scare.  These jump-scares are effective, but after the fourth time, it becomes routine.  Oh yes, and dolls are creepy.  We get it.  Dolls *are* creepy.Neverending Nightmares feels like it was built around its soundtrack.  The levels are ridiculously long just to make you absorb the music.  The ambient horror music makes this game, and it does a very good job creating atmosphere.  The art style is especially memorable.  I've never seen a game look like this, and it adds a lot to the creep factor.Steam won't let me give this a neutral rating, but it deserves one.  I didn't hate this game, as it did a very good job creating atmosphere and jump-scaring me more than once, but I found the delivery more tedious than scary, and the 3 payoffs at the end do not provide a satisfying resolution to all that marching.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												All in all, I think this game is a good starting point if you want to get into horror games. I mean that as a compliment.I wouldn't say that this game is necessarily bad. It's got a pretty good atmosphere and decent jumpscares. The artwork's great (they even make it easy to spot landmarks so that you don't get lost, even though pretty much everything's in black and white), and the voice acting is pretty good, as well. Each section of the game pretty much has its own unique set of monsters with the exception of one or two, and that gives a pretty good variety. It's short enough to show a friend to just play through really quickly - I got all of the paths in 3 hours.A lot of the time, I wasn't really that scared, which is sort of bad news for a horror game. While the atmosphere is pretty scary at first, it sort of fades once you actually get to see each of the monsters - the mystery sort of disappears, and it's really easy to learn how to deal with them pretty quickly. I think the main problem with this game is that it's just a ton of walking with only a small handful of scattered monsters or jumpscares in relatively few places. I don't want to make a joke like "Walking Simulator 2015" or anything like that, but that did make this game pretty boring. Like I said, if you want to get into horror games, this is a good place to start, but not for $15.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												I backed this game, and actually really liked the developer, but can't sugest this specific title to anyone else.It's beutiful, one of the best looking indie titles out there in my opinion, but there's not much else to call home about. Neverending nightmares is short, cliche, and most of the game is spent wandering through empty rooms with pictures of kickstarter backers on the wall. What's there to scare you is nothing you havent seen before in games like these, Giant babies, dudes with their eyes gouged out, a creepy girl. There's 2 genuine scares, great, clever moments, but bland outside of that.The whole thing can be finished in an hour and a half, and though there's multiple endings, but I cant bring myself to the tedium of wandering through empty rooms again to find them.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Asthma Simulator 2014. Seriously, someone please get the main character an inhaler!If you are expecting jump-scare style horror, ala Slender Man or Five Nights at Freddies you will probably be disappoint. Neverending Nightmares is an atmospheric horror in the artistic style of Edward Gorey and the story-telling of Edgar Allen Poe that delves into psychological terror with mood, eerie music and sounds, disturbing images, and a storyline that takes you into the depths of madness. It is simple gameplay but if you allow yourself to get immersed it is far more than a "Walking Simulator" as some claim it to be.The downside is that it is only 2-4 hours of gameplay if you want to go through each of the five paths to different endings (which I highly recommend to get a better idea what is truly transpiring in the story).8/10 Would get my intestines eaten by a faceless broken doll again.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												     "Neverending Nighmares" is a lovingly-crafted madness simulator.      Infinitap Studios strikes a forceful, gut-liquifying chord on their first foray into horror game-making. If you were to throw in a Cthulhu or two, the forum fanboys would be slavering. As it is, however, there's no eldritch forces pulling the strings in "Neverending Nightmares", only the fevered coding of a man who has experienced madness and sorrow without relief.      The mind behind this game, here we'll only call him Matt G., openly concedes that this game directly ties to the horror and pain in his own exeperinces with mental illness.  As such, gameplay is a constant drip of tense anxiety with each corridor, cupboard and cutscene and it never lets you off the hook. It's a constantly-dripping mindkcuf and it's GOOD.     I won't lie, "Neverending Nightmares" isn't for everyone. There's no escapism here.There's no HUD, no upgradable weapons, no unlockable weapons. No teamspeak.      In "Neverending Nightmares", you get a terrified young man in pyjamas, waking again in a gaslit bedroom after another nightmare. You won't get any points, but you will get to ride in a tortured mind and get to crawl around in his skin for a while - and that's something you don't see in a game too much.  You don't know a man until you've walked in his shoes and I take it that's kind of the whole point of this game.     Thanks to Matt G. and his dev team at Infinitap Games.  I don't know him, but I know where he's coming from. If nothing else, keep watching this studio.  They're swinging big, they're swinging hard, and their technique is flawless.    If you have the scratch and want to take a chance on "Neverending Nightmares", well...DO IT. If you don't like it, uninstall and take the refund. But I'm keeping mine and I'll be firing it back up right after I hug my wife and kid and let them know I love them more than anything. Good times,Doc Meow-30-

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												Neverending Nightmares may not be some ground breaking game, but it's certaintly not a bad one.It has it's moments when it comes to the "horror" aspect. Nothing too terryfing, just lovely instances from time to time that can make your heart skip a beat. But it's not really the kind of horror that's trying to be stressful, and make a player panic every other minute. It's strenght is more in the story, creepiness of the enviroment, overall confusion and mystery. The art style of the game is nice. It's simplistic yet creppy, and fits the atmosphere perfectly.There is a thing that not everyone may like and it's the gameplay itself. It is very simple. You won't find any puzzles to solve, items to carry around, brain teasers which would seem unsolvable only to make you feel like an idiot when you finally figure them out (or look for the answer on the internet). None of that.You also can't fight enemies, which is fine, but running away from them or avoiding them is also very easy to do.You basically walk around all the time which may feel a little boring after a while. Thankfully levels, and the game itself, aren't too long, and the enviroment changes so it's not that big of a deal.So if you don't mind all that, you know that hunger for answers will keep you going and you want to play a nice little horror game, then Neveredning Nightmares is a great recomendation.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												This game was *great!* It thoroughly delivered on the scares. The jump scares were effective; even when I was expecting one to pop up, it still managed to get a yelp out of me. The atmosphere was great; the art style and music really helped add a feeling of dread. The sound effects got very repetitive towards the end, though; the one of the woman crying started driving me crazy. The psychology behind it was also great! Like the creator, I live with mental illness and I identified with a lot of the emotion and struggle behind it. There aren't many puzzles and the gameplay is minimal, but it's more about the atmosphere than about the gameplay with a game like this in my opinion. All in all, though, this game delivered on the scares, and that's what I bought it for. 7/10.

Premise : i am sorry if my english is not perfect since i am italian and never studied english except from school and college, but i will review the games i play in english, just to reach more people.Second premise :  i just finished the game (even if not 100% tho) so my review will be very spontaneous.This game has many pros and cons.Pros : Very cool music (i like horror and weird pitched musics)           Xbox controller support (this was very very important to me)           Very cool graphic style (look gorgeous on high resolutions)           Lots of languages translations availableCons :  A little bit repetitive           Too much animal gore (too much slaughtered animals)Final thoughts  :  i wanna say the game is worth playing it since the pros (especially the controller support) make it pleasant to play.The fact that the game was pleasant can sound weird since is an horror game, but that's it,  it was not bad or stressfull to beat the game, or at least not so much stressfull  even becouse it does not take very much to beat the game (a bit less then 2 hours) wich is something i like instead of too much games that have nothing more to show then the same thing for hours and hours.

												Terrific art style clearly inspired by Edward Gorey, some genuine scares, a couple of gross-outs... but the disturbing atmosphere soon turns into momotony as you really do walk, and walk, and walk, quite a lot through seemingly endless iterations of the same hallway, over and over and over, until you begin to wonder if you're doing it right, if the game really will ever arrive somewhere. Worth getting if you're in need of some Halloween chills, but ONLY if you can get it at a significant discount. For my part -- there appear to be three alternate endings, but nothing in the world could get me to walk through this again right now. Maybe next Halloween.

												Good game. Since its initial release, I have played Neverending Nightmares several times and enjoyed the game each time. Its pros include:+ Good horror atmosphere+ Theme of the game, focused on nightmares and depression+ Original graphics+ Good music+ Nonconvential gameplay+ Several endings – at first I was trying to figure out, how the three endings fit together (had my own theory), but the developer explained in some discussion that these are in fact three separate storiesOften criticized is the game's length. I think the game is ok the way it is, but I would welcome some more content in the future (DLC, sequel, …), since I enjoyed the ride (or the walk to be more specific).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Neverending Nightmares is a short little game, but I would definitely recommend that any horror fan take the time to play through it. The one thing that I would strongly caution people of, is that there are parts of the game that are deeply unsettling particularly to anyone dealing with depression or self-harm issues, as some of the cutscenes and visuals strike pretty close to home in those areas. That being said, it's worth taking the time for.The storyline is good, a simple premise that is told in an interesting way, while being relatively easy to follow. The cutscenes are informative, but not overly long and they don't distract the player from the game too much.The gameplay itself is simple, and therefore easy enough to pick up, meaning you can jump right into the game itself without any lengthy tuturials, which is great. There aren't very many controls as the actions of your character are limited, but this simply fuels your desire not to run into any enemies, which is good since you really have no way to combat them. I tend to find that in horror titles, enemies that you can't fight have a higher psychological toll on the player and are therefore more effective generally speaking.The thing that I love most about this game is the artwork. The visual style of the game is incredibly unique and despite not being a terrifying style in and of itself, it's used in a way that adds to the atmosphere very well. The predominantly black and white color scheme is accented perfectly with just the items of importance being colored, which is a nice way to guide the player through the game without specifically telling them what to do. It also makes for some of the most visually appealing blood I've ever seen in a video game, just because the red on the black and white makes such a shark contrast.The one issue that I really had with the game was how slow the gameplay was in certain areas. As someone that doesn't have the best sense of direction, I had a tough time through some of the levels in regards to knowing where to go. I couldn't remember where I had been which made knowing which way to go difficult, and it became a bit tedious trying to figure it out when the character moves so slowly (though the slow movement speed does add suspense in a few places.) I also became annoyed only being able to use the run function for short distances, but it was a minor inconvenience.All in all, I would rate this game very highly and would feel good suggesting it to just about anyone.

Posted: February 17, 2015
												A great little indie horror game here! Not a ton of content but there is 4 different endings so the replay value is high. Mostly this is a walking sim with a ton of atmosphere but the way it is put together & it's story being open to your personal interpretation gives it a unique feel among similar games. I'm not gonna BS you, the game is short & lacks any type of real gameplay (i.e. no way to fight back against enemies, not much interaction with the enviroment) so if you're looking for horror game with action this not for you. On the other hand if you're looking for a unique horror experience & not adverse to more of an experience than a game this may be for you. IMO the only real con about this game is the price, I feel that $15 is a little steep for what it offers but if you can get it on sale I highly recommend this game.

Posted: March 18, 2015
												This game is a landmark in creating awareness in an epidemic which plagues many people in the world today: asthma. The developer has asthma himself, and by the end of the game, you will know what it feels like to walk a mile in his shoes. It brought me closer to my girlfriend who has asthma as well, and now I make sure to keep her spare inhaler with me at all times in case zombies or living dolls attack.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												This game is not for everyone, but for those it IS for - horror fans with a penchant for the disturbed and a slow burn to keep you on edge, rather than the gore  and jump scares that permeate modern horror - it will resonate within your psyche for a while. If you like fast-paced action, obvious story, open-world exploration, or your sanity, please move on, because you will find none of that here. However, for what this game is - an atmospheric horror game with an ambiguous story open to interpretation - it's fantastic. The game is short. There are 4 possible endings, and as of this review, I've completed 2 of them with only 2.4 hours on record, and even then there were a few times when I left the keyboard for a few minutes or would intentionally do something stupid just to see what would happen. Your first playthrough will only take about two hours (maybe less), then you can use a waypoint-like system to revisit earlier chapters to get to the other endings. I'm estimating 4-5 hours for completion of all 4 endings (assuming you use a spoiler-free guide to know where the branching points are, like I did).The game is very linear. But that's not always a bad thing. Not every game needs to be an open-world Bethesda behemoth. Linear works great for this game. It's high tension, and it manages to encourage exploration while still discouraging you from getting too far off the intended path. I won't explain how - because spoilers - but that's a tough act to balance, and this game does it without breaking the atmosphere.The art is, put simply, evocative. It holds multiple layers of detail. There were countless times when I took a closer look at a scene or a room I'd walked through before and realized the nuances I hadn't consciously observed prior, but at some level I know I witnessed them unconsciously and they added to the overall atmosphere.Don't even get me started on the soundtrack. Oh my god the soundtrack. I want the soundtrack as a standalone purchase for my horror-themed events. It's amazing background ambience, and it's superbly mixed with haunting sound effects to deliver an experience like none other, especially through headphones (the game highly recommends headphones and utilizes a special audio mixer for that immersive experience).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												TL:DR: this game is an expensive flash gameThe game has an interesting concept, but fails to make any relevant progress. It tries to become a survival horror, but takes shortcuts that make it feel more like a flash game than a full product. The best comparison is with P.T. which uses a similar idea: revisiting the same small area with minor changes at every iteration. Unfortunately, the game has you go into several rooms with no real progression. Each time you make a startling discovery or die, and end up in your bed. but the time to reach that climax is slow, stagnant, with an abrupt change. It lacks crescendo. There is a bare-bones stealth area where you hide in a closet while a grotesque baby-faced grunt shakes it. This mechanic is poorly developed, as you only have two directions to flee, and it is a matter of waiting until they are off-screen. I played one session and did not return, because only 1/5 of the game is actually content, and relies heavily on jump scares and exploration of mostly static environments. Items that you do examine are paintings with no interest or plot progression, as if they were added for either showing off artistic skills or lengthening gameplay.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												Asthma Simulator 2015.Seriously tho. I play every game about mental illnesses i can get my hands on and own piles of books about them, but the most nightmarish and disturbing thing about this game was the choice between moving at a snail's pace or running for 5 seconds and then stop and wheeze. It began really good, then everything repeated more or less eternally, while you struggle to move on...I can see, that this was a point the author may actually wanted to make, but it just turned out to be tedious, while it offered very little to make up for it. If it ends up in a bundle, i would recommend to try it out, but for 15 Euros (or 7 Euros for which I got it in the humble store) it isn't worth it in my opinion.

Posted: October 20, 2014
												This is a wonderful and eerie game.Its art style is thoughtfully curated, and reminiscent of Edward Gorey macabre illustrations.It's not a game about fighting, or running away from enemies, but one about an increasing sense of discomfort and tension. A deep sensation of wrongness ebbs from it, while you play, thanks to the maze of similar rooms creating confusion and preventing you from ever feel safe, and the masterfully crafted sound effects and music accompanying your actions.The most important aspects of this game are its atmosphere and its tone, and those are certainly excellent.If you let yourself immerse in this weird unsettling world of nightmares and weird dreams you are going to love it.

												Neverending Nightmares is an interesting, though short game. As someone who regularly seeks out horror in all its forms, I must say that this game really got under my skin. It felt visceral and even disturbing at times. I would recommend only looking up guides or playthroughs after your first playthrough if you desire to see the other paths. While the additional paths themselves don't seem to provide much more in the way of information, they do all contribute their own little bit to the overall mystery and narrative. If you are a fan of horror, and of walking, I would heartily recommend this.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												This game was *great!* It thoroughly delivered on the scares. The jump scares were effective; even when I was expecting one to pop up, it still managed to get a yelp out of me. The atmosphere was great; the art style and music really helped add a feeling of dread. The sound effects got very repetitive towards the end, though; the one of the woman crying started driving me crazy. The psychology behind it was also great! Like the creator, I live with mental illness and I identified with a lot of the emotion and struggle behind it. There aren't many puzzles and the gameplay is minimal, but it's more about the atmosphere than about the gameplay with a game like this in my opinion. All in all, though, this game delivered on the scares, and that's what I bought it for. 7/10.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												This is a surprisingly great game for such a simple thing. I can say, in all honesty, this game is making me nervous. I can also honestly say, I've never played anything like it....in terms of the gradual build of fear and tension is quite remarkable. I've played a few horro games....and most go for the usual "made you jump" scares. A few do what this one does. The game is based on the developers personal dealings with (one particular kind of) mental illness. This makes the game even more fascinating and horrible ....In a good way? Good for us. You will be sure it wasn't good for him. I wouldn't have imagined that a bunch of somewhat squiggly line drawings (well done though) would wind up getting under my skin. He uses the art style to impressive effect. If you're looking for something different, something disturbing ,that plays mind tricks as well as throwing in the sudden scary images and weirdness, this game is the one.I forgot to add, headphones are a must.Edit: ------I occassionaly feel the urge to stop playing because it really unnerves me that this poor guy was dealing with this level of madness. ON THE OTHER HAND.....I don't like it when mental "illness" (they have to come up with a better term) is always portrayed as sopmething horrifying and violent. You see on the newsw how they make blanket statements concerning some terrible incident , lilke a school shooting, in which mentally ill is used with extreme negativity....as if there's only one kind of mental illness . And that it always ends in violence and death. I have someone inmy family who is bipolar. Yeah, he can get pretty out there....liek a person on speed or something. But, he doesn'thurt other people. Sadly, he hurts himself. So, there's that. Inthis fellows case, I believe he suffered from breaks from reality due to schizophrenia. They are the specific type of mental illness that can evolve into violence. This isk because the person is so disconnected from the real world and normal thinking, that they could very well hurt others believing they were a threat....or that they're demonic or some other thing. People with depression are more likely to hurt themselves. Autistic kids can turn violent as they get older. I don't know enough to tell you why. My point is, there are many different diagnosis that fall under the same umbrella.....and that's really not helpful in any way.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												This game is very disturbing in every way that it intends to be. The enemy designs are very chilling and seeing any of them made my heart race. The atmosphere was amazing and I always felt alone and scared. The music was nightmarish at times, it definitely compliments the great atmosphere. The only thing about this game is that it's more of an artistic represintation of the developers battle with insanity than an actual game. I have no problem with it, I loved this game, but those who are looking for a more interactive experince may be let down. The game isn't very long, either. If you don't see yourself happy with about two hours of game time for the price then you may want to pass this up. At least until it's on sale, in which case I highly recommend you get it. Neverending Nightmares was a fantastic experience, and it has been one of the few horror games that I have finished and didn't stop thinking about it. The way the game is presented is fantastic and I would love to something else from the creator of this game. TL;DR Fantastic horror experience with a rich atmosphere and chilling designs that is well worth your money, just so long as you don't mind the small length of the game(about 2 hours). 8/10
