content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												I've wanted to play Neverending Nightmares for quite some time, and now that I have I can say that I really enjoyed it.The first thing that drew me in was the art style, it's a little different to a lot of what's out there, especially within the genre. The art style is also very fitting for the game and its subject matter. Then the story itself was intriguing to me, as someone fascinated with dreams and nightmares who experiences a lot of both the premise meant the game was bound to interest me.Yes, the game is rather short, but I don't think that's necessarily a bad thing. I often enjoy short games, they can be just the thing when you fancy playing something but have other things going on. It also keeps the game from being repetitive, in order to make this game longer a lot of new creatures and endings would have needed to be added, by which point the plot would run the risk of getting stretched too thin. I feel like Neverending Nightmares strikes the perfect balance for those who don't mind if a game is short.As far as how scary this game is, that'd depend on what gets to you, for instance, for a person afraid of dolls a large portion of this game would be very creepy. For me there were other things that would creep me out, I'm afraid of the dark and stairs make me very uneasy. They have covered a lot of based and there were a couple of bits where I jumped (although I'm admittedly easily startled).Lastly, I'd say that while I definitely recommend this game to people who don't mind a short psychological horror experience that isn't action-oriented, if you are sensitive to imagery or references to suicide or self harm then this game will likely not be for you, so basically, player discretion is advised.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												As gaming matures so does it’s themes. In recent years there has been a slew of more or less interactive games about mental illnesses, perhaps the most discussed being Depression Quest. Neverending Nightmares is also said to be based on the developers own experience living with ocd and depression, but where Depression Quest was a choose-your-own-adventure text based game this time we have a proper adventure game. Or what at first glance looks like a proper game. Yes there is a character to control and progress to be made but don’t be fooled to think there is much more gameplay here. The whole game consists of walking endless corridors, sometimes opening doors or clumsily trying to avoid a few monsters. The striking art style is admirable, in still pictures it resembles some crude underground comic from yesteryear and in motion the facial expressions and body language of the main character helps transfer a feeling of utter despair and terror as you blindly navigate the endless corridors. But here also lies it’s main problem - sure the atmosphere is there but it’s not used to tell the gamer anything, the story is non-existent until the very end. While I can sympathise with the design decision to keep with the theme of a looping, never ending nightmare it also takes away the incentive to keep playing as you are not given any reason to do so. In the end it was an empty experience more filled with boredom than horror.

												NEN is an interesting game. I backed this on Kickstarter because the creator had an interesting idea I wanted to see flourish into a game. I purchased this and didn't immediately play it but I did save the game for my 2014 Extra-Life charity stream. I played through, and beat, the game in about 1.5 hours. Those 1.5 hours weren't exceptionally difficult nor were they thought provoking. The only reason the things in the game meant anything to me was because I Kickstarted the game and knew that the game creator focused the game around his own anxieties and fears. This doesn't really come through in the game if you don't know those things.I hate to base a review around the price of a game but I don't know...this is a coin toss for me. I'm going to not recommend this game. All you do is walk left or right...there aren't any puzzles, there isn't any dialogue, the scares are telegraphed and not especially scary (subjective, I know), and the short nature of the game make it really hard to recommend. If you want to pick it up I would say get it as cheap as possible. Your mileage may vary but I felt this was a huge letdown.

												This game doesn't strike me as a game under the usual terms (minus the few super annoying bits). The entire thing is crafted by someone who is personally connected to it and it shows. It won't be for everyone. I feel like it is a strong experience, not even just as a game. This is what art is, game aside. It is a well thought through project and almost each aspect definately agonized over. The visuals are stunningly different, stark and constantly changing. It feel monotonous and confusing as you play like the feelings trying to be shown by the character. The lack of colouration makes the crosshatching and pops of colour really work and the layers of marks for darkness give darkness something more than blank black, almost character. I'd love to see the assets for this game turned into a comic.Where this game does fall down is in execution of interactivity. I 100%ed this game in like 4 hours, despite the character walking so slowly and being almost incapable of running. The Ai in the game is also very rudimentary and movement is stilted and weird.   DO NOT PLAY WITHOUT HEADPHONES AND BE READY FOR USE OF BINAURAL BEATSit will make you feel weird and sink into the game more, it made me uncomfortable which was the creators desired effect. I may have liked a warning as to what the "special headphone mix" was though.One last thing this is the first game I've played that made use of the lighting effects on my alienware and it was sweet.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												A dreamlike exploration of living with mental illness, Neverending Nightmares gets a lot of mileage out of a rather constrained setting. Even before the branching plotlines and multiple endings, the game's trio of primary settings offer more than enough dread to deal with.Despite its admitted inspiration in struggles with OCD and depression, Neverending Nightmares opts for a more metaphorical take on its subject matter than anything literal. The game looks at what such struggles feel like, or felt like for the creator at least, through the lens of horror rather than attempting to recount the experience directly. The bulk of the game involves waking up to an eerie, foreboding environment that only slightly changes with each return to supposed consciousness. Every wakeup is followed by a new attempt to find a way out of these increasingly imposing scenarios, searching each area for new tools to progress and usually ending in an unexpectedly horrible way. As things progress, human-but-not-quite creatures join the environment in trying to stop you, but never quite to the point of being a showdown. Even though this realm is apparently your own mind, you have no real power here.The game's monochrome visual style is striking and memorable, with some interesting techniques used to add gloom and otherwise obfuscate areas when necessary. The only color that comes into play is red, which is used selectively but liberally for gore when warranted. The soundtrack is subtle, but haunting, and what few sounds the handful of enemies make when you encounter them are enough on their own to make it clear they should be avoided.Neverending Nightmares does a great job of managing difficulty as well. Puzzles often rely on a bit of wandering at first to trigger certain appearances, but don't feel overly drawn out. Enemies are easy enough to avoid in most cases, with later encounters taking a bit more strategy, and the consequences for failure feel justified but horrifying. As things increase in difficulty and complexity, levels offer checkpoints to keep repetition down.The multiple endings aren't overly numerous, and I liked how it wasn't entirely clear which one, if any of them, was the "real" ending. As you finish the game, a level map unlocks, showing threads between what you've cleared thus far and making it easier to figure out where you should be looking for alternate choices to enable different progress. All in all, this is one neat little horror package, and the connection it has to the developer's personal experience makes it that much more worthwhile.Here's a little peek at what you're in for, if you're curious: 


YouTube™ Video: Sketched Horror ➸ The Never Ending Nightmare Part 1

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Don’t let the hand-drawn look of this game fool you (though this was one of the things that first brought this game to my attention), for it is profoundly disturbing and deeply psychological.  There is the stark contrast of black and white throughout, often offset by traces of blood and certain other colors for objects that you can interact with.  Perhaps interact isn’t the proper word to use here; more like ‘look’ at, as this game doesn’t utilize an inventory system and there are no collectibles of any kind to pick up along the way.  Also, it’s extremely short and likely won’t take you more than 30 – 45 min. to complete, though there are a few different endings of sorts, and branching pathways leading up to said endings for you to discover, which adds replay value.  The length is the only gripe I can envision people having with Unending Nightmares, especially when considering the $15 price tag, so you may want to get it when it’s on sale. Some may find the lack of objectives/puzzle elements and an inventory system as something to complain about, but I personally found those aspects of this game to be something of a breath of fresh air that in no way seems to detract from the allure of this game.  The psychological aspect of Unending Nightmares harkens back to the earlier days of Silent Hill; its often disjointed plot progression does make sense (at least a little bit) in the end, but regardless of what you may think about that, you’ll be left feeling the same sense of confusion/fear/loss that the protagonist (Thomas) suffers through, which are emotions too few games horror games elicit in the player. And lastly, let’s not forget about one of the most important (arguably THE most important) aspect of any horror game – the sound. The sound design of Unending Nightmares is, in a word, remarkable; vastly more balanced and disturbing than I would have expected from an indie horror game. The effects and ambience are truly haunting and will stay with you long after you finish playing the game. The snatches of speech throughout are also nice and the voice acting is decent despite the brief nature of these moments in the game.I definitely recommend that you give this game a chance, and even if you can’t get it on sale, all the aforementioned aspects work so well together that you won’t regret paying full price.  Definitely a gem in a flagging genre that is increasingly becoming riddled with games that developers have put little effort into making a compelling experience in the way they once were.

												Excellent art, with such find attention to detail and nuance.  Although I found the art style immediately compelling, I was a little concerned that it would prevent me from getting creeped out.  That was a foolish concern, the game does a gret job of building tension and dread, and providing some satisfying creepiness.  I had the computer hooked up to the television so my partner could watch as I played, and there was one moment were we both actually shouted and jumped out of our seats,  one of the jumps scares got us so good.  (Though note, there are very few jump scares in the game, it most relies on atmosphere, story, and sound for it's scares.)Apparently there are several story branches, and it looks like you do get some differences in game play at a certain point toward the end of the game.  So it may offer some replay value for those of you who like to see all the different endings.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												NEN is an interesting game. I backed this on Kickstarter because the creator had an interesting idea I wanted to see flourish into a game. I purchased this and didn't immediately play it but I did save the game for my 2014 Extra-Life charity stream. I played through, and beat, the game in about 1.5 hours. Those 1.5 hours weren't exceptionally difficult nor were they thought provoking. The only reason the things in the game meant anything to me was because I Kickstarted the game and knew that the game creator focused the game around his own anxieties and fears. This doesn't really come through in the game if you don't know those things.I hate to base a review around the price of a game but I don't know...this is a coin toss for me. I'm going to not recommend this game. All you do is walk left or right...there aren't any puzzles, there isn't any dialogue, the scares are telegraphed and not especially scary (subjective, I know), and the short nature of the game make it really hard to recommend. If you want to pick it up I would say get it as cheap as possible. Your mileage may vary but I felt this was a huge letdown.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												I've wanted to play Neverending Nightmares for quite some time, and now that I have I can say that I really enjoyed it.The first thing that drew me in was the art style, it's a little different to a lot of what's out there, especially within the genre. The art style is also very fitting for the game and its subject matter. Then the story itself was intriguing to me, as someone fascinated with dreams and nightmares who experiences a lot of both the premise meant the game was bound to interest me.Yes, the game is rather short, but I don't think that's necessarily a bad thing. I often enjoy short games, they can be just the thing when you fancy playing something but have other things going on. It also keeps the game from being repetitive, in order to make this game longer a lot of new creatures and endings would have needed to be added, by which point the plot would run the risk of getting stretched too thin. I feel like Neverending Nightmares strikes the perfect balance for those who don't mind if a game is short.As far as how scary this game is, that'd depend on what gets to you, for instance, for a person afraid of dolls a large portion of this game would be very creepy. For me there were other things that would creep me out, I'm afraid of the dark and stairs make me very uneasy. They have covered a lot of based and there were a couple of bits where I jumped (although I'm admittedly easily startled).Lastly, I'd say that while I definitely recommend this game to people who don't mind a short psychological horror experience that isn't action-oriented, if you are sensitive to imagery or references to suicide or self harm then this game will likely not be for you, so basically, player discretion is advised.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												I see that this game has some polarizing reviews, but as a fan of atmospheric horror games I enjoyed it! I think it did what it set out to do perfectly. The cryptic storyline makes you draw your own conclusions and even question what really happened.Your character walks slowly and can't run for long, which adds to your vulnerability. You can't kill enemies, just avoid them. You run through a series of doors and rooms in repeating waking nightmares.The hand drawn art style is unique, detailed and looks great. There is plenty of disturbing imagery, a few jump scares, and some subtle creepy moments. When it's on sale, I can easily recommend it to other fans of the genre!

												I don't normally like to write reviews about anything (games, movies, music, books, etc.) because I don't consider myself to be an expert in anything and therefore don't feel qualified to share my opinion, but I feel moved to share my experience with Neverending Nightmares. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												As gaming matures so does it’s themes. In recent years there has been a slew of more or less interactive games about mental illnesses, perhaps the most discussed being Depression Quest. Neverending Nightmares is also said to be based on the developers own experience living with ocd and depression, but where Depression Quest was a choose-your-own-adventure text based game this time we have a proper adventure game. Or what at first glance looks like a proper game. Yes there is a character to control and progress to be made but don’t be fooled to think there is much more gameplay here. The whole game consists of walking endless corridors, sometimes opening doors or clumsily trying to avoid a few monsters. The striking art style is admirable, in still pictures it resembles some crude underground comic from yesteryear and in motion the facial expressions and body language of the main character helps transfer a feeling of utter despair and terror as you blindly navigate the endless corridors. But here also lies it’s main problem - sure the atmosphere is there but it’s not used to tell the gamer anything, the story is non-existent until the very end. While I can sympathise with the design decision to keep with the theme of a looping, never ending nightmare it also takes away the incentive to keep playing as you are not given any reason to do so. In the end it was an empty experience more filled with boredom than horror.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												A dreamlike exploration of living with mental illness, Neverending Nightmares gets a lot of mileage out of a rather constrained setting. Even before the branching plotlines and multiple endings, the game's trio of primary settings offer more than enough dread to deal with.Despite its admitted inspiration in struggles with OCD and depression, Neverending Nightmares opts for a more metaphorical take on its subject matter than anything literal. The game looks at what such struggles feel like, or felt like for the creator at least, through the lens of horror rather than attempting to recount the experience directly. The bulk of the game involves waking up to an eerie, foreboding environment that only slightly changes with each return to supposed consciousness. Every wakeup is followed by a new attempt to find a way out of these increasingly imposing scenarios, searching each area for new tools to progress and usually ending in an unexpectedly horrible way. As things progress, human-but-not-quite creatures join the environment in trying to stop you, but never quite to the point of being a showdown. Even though this realm is apparently your own mind, you have no real power here.The game's monochrome visual style is striking and memorable, with some interesting techniques used to add gloom and otherwise obfuscate areas when necessary. The only color that comes into play is red, which is used selectively but liberally for gore when warranted. The soundtrack is subtle, but haunting, and what few sounds the handful of enemies make when you encounter them are enough on their own to make it clear they should be avoided.Neverending Nightmares does a great job of managing difficulty as well. Puzzles often rely on a bit of wandering at first to trigger certain appearances, but don't feel overly drawn out. Enemies are easy enough to avoid in most cases, with later encounters taking a bit more strategy, and the consequences for failure feel justified but horrifying. As things increase in difficulty and complexity, levels offer checkpoints to keep repetition down.The multiple endings aren't overly numerous, and I liked how it wasn't entirely clear which one, if any of them, was the "real" ending. As you finish the game, a level map unlocks, showing threads between what you've cleared thus far and making it easier to figure out where you should be looking for alternate choices to enable different progress. All in all, this is one neat little horror package, and the connection it has to the developer's personal experience makes it that much more worthwhile.Here's a little peek at what you're in for, if you're curious: 


YouTube™ Video: Sketched Horror ➸ The Never Ending Nightmare Part 1

												Pros:-Very Atmospheric.-Has a very interesting graphic design.-Some what great story.-Choices.-Great choice of soundtrack which adds some creepyness in the game.-Nice lighting system to represent the darkness.Cons:-The sprinting system, while you will be sprinting you're still going to be the slowest character in the game and constantly run out of breath for every 5 seconds which can be frustrating.-Lack of things to do within so many rooms in the game, mostly just explore and look around.-Lack of backstory and explanation to different endings within the game.-Can get really boring if you get lost on one of the chapters and then you start walking circles.I would recommend this game to anyone who is afraid of the dark, play this with headphones in the dark in the middle of the night for the best horror experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												Neverending Nightmares may not be some ground breaking game, but it's certaintly not a bad one.It has it's moments when it comes to the "horror" aspect. Nothing too terryfing, just lovely instances from time to time that can make your heart skip a beat. But it's not really the kind of horror that's trying to be stressful, and make a player panic every other minute. It's strenght is more in the story, creepiness of the enviroment, overall confusion and mystery. The art style of the game is nice. It's simplistic yet creppy, and fits the atmosphere perfectly.There is a thing that not everyone may like and it's the gameplay itself. It is very simple. You won't find any puzzles to solve, items to carry around, brain teasers which would seem unsolvable only to make you feel like an idiot when you finally figure them out (or look for the answer on the internet). None of that.You also can't fight enemies, which is fine, but running away from them or avoiding them is also very easy to do.You basically walk around all the time which may feel a little boring after a while. Thankfully levels, and the game itself, aren't too long, and the enviroment changes so it's not that big of a deal.So if you don't mind all that, you know that hunger for answers will keep you going and you want to play a nice little horror game, then Neveredning Nightmares is a great recomendation.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												Excellent art, with such find attention to detail and nuance.  Although I found the art style immediately compelling, I was a little concerned that it would prevent me from getting creeped out.  That was a foolish concern, the game does a gret job of building tension and dread, and providing some satisfying creepiness.  I had the computer hooked up to the television so my partner could watch as I played, and there was one moment were we both actually shouted and jumped out of our seats,  one of the jumps scares got us so good.  (Though note, there are very few jump scares in the game, it most relies on atmosphere, story, and sound for it's scares.)Apparently there are several story branches, and it looks like you do get some differences in game play at a certain point toward the end of the game.  So it may offer some replay value for those of you who like to see all the different endings.
